âI am pleased to be able to stand today to discuss yesterday's joint announcement by the Attorney-General and the Minister for Aged Care that the government will abolish compulsory age retirement limits for statutory office holders. That is subject to suitable exemptions for particular office holders, such as those in the military service.

speech.para: Many in this chamber may remember back when Labor was in government when Senator Baume and I teamed up time and time again to move amendments to enable people serving on boards of statutory authorities to remain in those positions after the age of 65. Labor always found some impediment or some excuse as to why they could not bring in a bill to do this in an overall manner. Every time a bill came into the chamber which had a particular statutory authority associated with it, Senator Baume and I would move amendments to eliminate the compulsory retirement age. There was absolutely no commitment at all by Labor to abolish discrimination in this form against older people.

It is especially appropriate that the progressive amendment of legislation to abolish age requirements for statutory office holders occur during this year, the International Year of Older Persons; a year in which the government is committed to looking across all portfolios to address issues of ageism. The department will look to do something to promote older people, to make life easier for older people or to do something that will facilitate things for older people. Every department is committed in the celebration of the International Year of Older Persons to addressing their own portfolios to see whether there are things that can be done. I am delighted to see that this is just one example of the outcome of our planning over the last 18 months for this international year.

Labor's record of inaction on age discrimination is nothing short of shameful. In 1990 the then minister for social security, Graham Richardson, gave an undertaking to remove age discrimination from all existing federal legislation. The promise was never delivered. In 1993 Senator Nick Bolkus stated:
The Attorney-General's Department is working towards the development of a comprehensive Commonwealth age discrimination policy.

That was never delivered. As I said, Senator Baume and I, in that environment and that climate, teamed up to move amendments to enable people serving on boards of statutory authorities to remain after the age of 65.

When I was shadow minister for senior citizens, aged care, women and the arts, I visited the National Maritime Museum. They gave me a perfect example of a retired naval officer who was just 65, who had been serving on the National Maritime Museum with all his maritime experience, with all his naval experience and was going to have to retire from the museum board because he had turned 65. Yet only yesterday I heard on the radio of an Australian doctor who is working in Ethiopia, serving the people in Ethiopia, women in particular who have fistulas and who are outcasts in their communities as a result of the incontinence that comes from that. She is 75 years of age and still operat ing. She had come home to have a cataract removed so that she could continue her work. She is still operating and says that she has no intention of retiring. There she is at 75, an Australian doctor over the last 40 years making a tremendous contribution to Ethiopia. She is a tremendous example of the work that Australians are doing here and overseas well into their 70s and 80s. To say that somebody has to retire at 65 is absolutely outrageous.

Labor had no will and no determination to do anything about it. They always found an impediment. They always found a problem with allowing people over age 65 to serve on statutory authorities and to continue working in the Public Service. The weak argument they kept bringing up with regard to people over 65 working in the Public Service was about compensation. When would compensation end if they got sick? It seemed to be within the wit of almost every other state jurisdiction to find out how to solve that, but not the Labor Party when it was in government.

There was absolutely no commitment by Labor to abolish discrimination against older people. There was absolutely no recognition by them, in turn, that people over 65 had anything to offer in terms of wisdom and experience. Under Labor we were losing wisdom and experience, losing a contribution that older people could make. By contrast, the abolition of compulsory retirement has been part of Liberal policy since 1988. But, unlike Labor, who are all talk and no action, we have done something about it.

The coalition has always believed that it is in our national interest to ensure that our mature and skilled work force is productively employed as long as possible. In 1992 I introduced the Public Service (Abolition of Compulsory Retirement Age) Amendment Bill. It was in the Senate and it lapsed. We had an election, and I resubmitted the private member's bill in 1995. The bill lay on the table of the Senate. There was no action from the Labor Party. They would not bring the bill on for debate. They always found some excuse.

It has taken a coalition government to put into action real and effective changes to address this inequity. We did it in opposition as far as we could by bringing in amendments. We had agreement from the Democrats to support those amendments. It took the coalition to begin planning for the International Year of Older Persons and to see this legislation, which was announced yesterday about the elimination of compulsory retirement at 65 for statutory authorities, brought on for debate.

We had a Public Service Bill before this chamber in the last parliament which had a number of reforms which would have allowed for a dynamic and flexible Public Service. The bill was vital for good government and effective delivery of quality of services to the public. We saw a huge number of amendments from Labor that, as Dr David Kemp said, were a great `backward leap'. He went on to say, and I quote from a press release he put out:
They are unduly prescriptive and contain excessive regulatory controls, which could lead to reduced levels of service to the public and less satisfying work conditions for staff.

That bill was brought in here twice. The opposition parties tried to amend it. The government would not accept those amendments. But hidden in that event was the loss of the abolition of the compulsory retirement age of 65, because in that bill were a number of clauses which would remove compulsory retirement for public servants.

I cannot tell senators how often public servants have come up to meâattendants here in Parliament House and various people I come in contact withâwhen I brought those private member's bills in and said, `I would like to be able to continue working but I cannot.' I see people like my father, who at 76 is still running a factory and working five days a week, and that doctor I mentioned, who at 75 is still working in Ethiopia.

There are some public servants, not a huge number, who would like to continue working, especially those public servants who have been on lower incomes. They may have come into the work force later. They may be women who have come back into the work force or have been widowed or, for some reason, their incomes have been low and who would be eligible for the pension at 65. If they were able to continue working in the Public Service on a part-time basis for 20 hours a week, if they were eligible at 65 for the pensionâand there could be women who are a little younger, as we are phasing in the pension age of 65 for womenâand able to continue working for five years, they would be eligible for a bonus of $21,000 tax free for a single person or $35,000 for a couple. For many of those people that is an amount of money they would never save in their whole lifetimes. But because that legislation was defeated in the chamber in the last parliament, that chance is not there for them.

They miss out in two ways: not only those who want to continue working will miss out on being able to continue working but also those who would be eligible for a pension and who would have been able to continue working will miss out on the bonus. I want honourable senators, when Minister Kemp returns that bill to this chamber, to think very carefully about what they are doing. It might not matter for people in here who stand to get a pension. What they are doing is denying those people who are on the cuspâaged 63, 64 or 65. They do not have time to wait for us to fiddle here. They want the answer now. They want that discrimination taken out of the bill now because it affects them personally.

I want honourable senators to think about that when that bill returns, as no doubt Dr Kemp will again attempt to reform the Public Service. The Public Service Act has been around for 75 years and been subject to hundreds of amendments. It was due for reform. It was due to be changed. But my particular interest in the Public Service Bill was the clauses that abolish the compulsory retirement age of 65.

I commend the Attorney-General and I commend the Minister for Aged Care for bringing this reform forward to eliminate the compulsory retirement age for statutory office holders. I think it is a great contribution and another example of eliminating discrimination within our society, within our community, and yet another example of the government's commitment to the International Year of Older Persons.

talk.start.para: âThe Labor Party has on a number of occasions in this chamber raised serious issues about the behaviour, history and ethics of the Liberal Party's pollster, Mark Textor. We have done this for two reasons. Firstly, Mr Textor's sordid history raises serious concerns about his fitness to obtain the many government research contracts which increasingly appear to be going his way. Revelations about his past behaviour in the Northern Territory and as the pollster behind the disgraceful Canberra by-election push polling scandal show his actions to be unethical, illegal and immoral.

speech.para: Secondly, we raise these matters to exposeâand by exposing we hope to endâthe disturbing rise of wedge politics of which Mark Textor is an unashamed practitioner. Wedge politics operates on the cynical and shameful political calculation that you can win in politics only when you divide the community. His research methodology is designed to identify, exploit and inflame division for the benefit of his political clientele.

Understandably, Mark Textor is not happy with the attention he is getting over the allegations we have brought into this place. He and his political masters are best served by his ongoing anonymity and lack of accountability. His defence has been a mixture of flat denial and counterattack in the face of overwhelming and irrefutable evidence. Mark Textor thinks he is a brilliant pollster who strikes fear into the heart of the Labor Party. He no doubt delights in that self-delusion. His defenders in the Liberal Party also claim that we are out to get him because he is a strategic genius. He is and they are sadly misguided.

The Labor Party is not frightened of Mark Textor. We regard him as far from brilliant. We are not intimidated by his strategic genius, because we see no evidence that he possesses any. The only genius uncovered in Mark Textor's polling in 1998 should be attributed to the Labor Party campaign. If you believe his figures published in the Bulletin, Labor's primary vote jumped by seven points over the course of the campaign period.

We were also intrigued by the Liberal's failure to exert pressure on Labor in a number of areas where our own research showed us to be a little vulnerable. We waited and waited, but the assault never came. Instead, we watched as the Liberal Party resorted to polluting the letter boxes of elderly Australians with direct mail on our capital gains tax policyâa scare campaign that singularly failed to make a dent in our support, even amongst the groups it targeted.

We object to Mark Textor because as a market researcher and pollster he is ethically unscrupulous, unprofessional andâjudging by his outlandish poll numbers published in the Bulletin before last year's electionâincompetent. As a concrete example of Mark Textor's unethical and unprofessional research methods, the Labor Party has obtained videotapes of focus groups Mark Textor conducted in 1993 in the Northern Territory as director of his front company, Territory Focus Consulting. Territory Focus Consulting had entered into a contract with the Northern Territory government to conduct focus group research into community perceptions of government policy and programs.

The use of taxpayers' money for government research can be for legitimate purposes. An example would be the testing of community perceptions on the provision of health or education services using legitimate research methods. This was clearly not the case with the research performed under the contract Textor signed with the Northern Territory Chief Minister's Department on 14 April 1993 and through which Textor was paid $740 a day of Northern Territory taxpayers' money. The contract, issued without any tender process, was hastily put together at the behest of the Country Liberal Party. It was arranged by Mr Paul Cowdy, who at the time worked for CLP Chief Minister Marshall Perron. Textor wrote to Paul Cowdy on 19 April 1993 in an attempt to present the research as a bona fide use of taxpayers' money. Cowdy also witnessed Textor's signature on the $740 a day contract. Cowdy now sits at the right hand of the current CLP Chief Minister, Denis Burke, as his senior political adviser. Andrew Coward, the confessed co-conspirator, supervised the contract as the key operative in Marshall Perron's office.

We have stated earlier that this contract was a sham. The videotapes of the 1993 focus groups now provide graphic evidence that this contract represents a blatant and improper abuse of the established convention that taxpayers' money should not be used for covert party political purposes. The videosâof two separate focus group discussions held on the same day in April 1993âshow that Mark Textor relentlessly pursued political lines of inquiry, such as:

Who is the Chief Minister and how would you describe him? Have you heard of the Leader of the Opposition before today? If there were one word to describe him, what would it be? So we are on Brian Edeâwhat do you think of him? How would you describe him? Why is land rights a bad thing? Would you vote for the crowd that is in or the crowd that is out? Just before I give you your dough, let's go around the table. If you had to make a hard decision, which way would you go?

This is the stuff of political focus groups, pure and simple. And it should have been paid for by the end user of the research dataâthe Northern Territory Country Liberal Party. This is simply a more direct version of the 1990 strategy devised by Mark Textor and enacted by Brian Sweeney and Associates where Northern Territory taxpayers paid the overwhelming majority of the cost of the focus groups and where two reports resulted, with the more useful and detailed report going exclusively to the CLP.

The videos also show Textor testing out divisive issues to be slotted into CLP wedge politics campaigns, with direct questions on land rights, ownership and control of national parks and excessive government interference in the Territory's unrestricted lifestyle. He was teasing out language and concepts for the use of the CLP in the 1994 election. He was doing it on the payroll of the Northern Territory government in direct breach of at least section 45 of the Northern Territory Self-Government Act.

As he grilled these unsuspecting participants for their political insights, in a room nearby on closed-circuit television sat a number of CLP political operatives, including Andrew Coward from the Chief Minister's office. Think about this for one momentâa party official sitting in on party-political focus group research corruptly commissioned by the Northern Territory government and funded out the pockets of taxpayers.

And now we come to the lies. In the course of the focus group sessions, Mark Textor wilfully lied repeatedly. He lied about his client. He claimed on one occasion that he was working for businesses down south and on another that he had no client at all but would sell the research to the highest bidder once completed. In fact, when specifically asked whether he was working for the Liberal or Labor governments, he explicitly denied that. In fact, his nominal client was the Northern Territory governmentâat least that is who paid his fee. His real client was the CLP.

He lied about the video. He claimed that the video was for his use only and would be taped over or destroyed immediately after the session was completed. In fact, it was not a stand-alone video recorder but a closed-circuit television beamed into a neighbouring room for the benefit of interested but unidentified onlookers. And the video was never taped over or destroyed but was kept indefinitely in the files of the CLP.

He lied about himself. He claimed he knew nothing about the Northern Territory, having, he said, only spent six months there a few years ago. In fact, Mark Textor was born and raised in Darwin. It was where he cut his political teeth. As a member of the Market Research Society of Australia, he is bound by the professional code of conduct that governs the industry. Under these guidelines Mark Textor is not obliged to reveal his client, and that is fair enough. But creating fictional clients to appease concerned participants is a clear breach. Lying about his own personal history was simply gratuitous dishonesty.

A market researcher is permitted to take video recordings of his focus groups, but only when he or she explicitly spells out what they intend to do with them and gains approval from the interviewees. He is also obliged under the guidelines to inform the group if a closed-circuit television is in use and, if so, who is watching. He did neither. As a market researcher he is further obliged to protect the security of the tapes and thereby the privacy of the participants. The fact that in 1999 we have obtained copies of the five-year-old tapes amply illustrates that he failed to do this as well.

Irresponsibly, Mark Textor plied the participants with alcoholâno doubt in an attempt to elicit their innermost feelingsâand then stood by as many pulled out their car keys and made their way home. Mark Textor was consistently and flagrantly in breach of the code of professional conduct that governs his profession. He lied, allowed unauthorised parties to witness the proceedings, failed to protect the privacy of the participants and calmly watched them leave to drive home, intoxicated from the alcohol he provided.

This new evidence shows he is a market researcher of the most unethical, irresponsible and deceitful kind who, through his actions, has brought his profession into disrepute. Along with Andrew Robb, Mark Textor has been forced to pay a price for his corrupt and despicable actions as a Liberal Party political operative, specifically in paying substantial damages and apologising to the Labor Party candidate in the 1995 Canberra by-election. This was a specific admission that Mark Textor and the Liberal Party had used push polling techniques during an election campaign.

There have been more recent examples of the Liberal Party using these abhorrent push polling methods, where personally damaging lies are knowingly peddled to sway individuals' voting intentions under the guise of polling activity. The Labor Party is aware of at least two instances where this has been used by the Liberal Party recentlyâduring the by-election in the NSW state seat of Sutherland and in Drummoyne during the current NSW state election campaign.

Similarly, the Labor Party has a range of serious questions regarding the federal government contracts going to Mark Textor's main company, Australasian Research Strategies. For instance, just before the 1998 election Mark Textor received contracts to undertake polling research in two highly political and controversial areasânamely, community attitudes on the environmental issues for the Natural Heritage Trust and on industrial relations issues for the research document attached to the leaked Reith letter to the Prime Minister.

In regard to this very recent polling, we ask the Howard government: how much did these two research contracts cost the Commonwealth taxpayer? Was a proper competitive tendering process undertaken for these contracts? Was there any political interference in this tendering, the contracting, or the drafting of the tasks to be undertaken? And, most importantly, how can Commonwealth taxpayers be assured that the highly political data gathered by Mark Textor and paid for by the Commonwealth taxpayer was not passed on to the Liberal Party for use in the 1998 federal election campaign?

The evidence we have outlined today demonstrates the tactics used in recent years by Mark Textor and the Liberal Party in abusing Commonwealth taxpayers' money to conduct blatantly political research. We now require the Howard government to come clean on how these fraudulent tactics have been used to spend public funds on political research for the 1998 federal election campaign. If the government will not come clean on these matters, it is our view that parliament may need to seek full details of Mr Textor's taxpayer funded political research through a wide-reaching parliamentary inquiry. The Labor Party is not raising these questions through partisan politics motivated by jealousy or self-interest on our part. Indeed, it is in our interest that the Liberal Party continues to rely on such wildly inaccurate polling. The true act of partisanship here would be for the coalition to continue to protect and defend Textor when that defence taints them with the very corruption and moral bankruptcy that he represents.

talk.start.para: âToday I want to speak in this debate about a concern I have with the federal government, particularly with their decision to de-fund the Acid Sulfate Soil Research Program of CSIRO. I am not only concerned about this; through this speech I urge the government to restore that funding because there is no doubt that this is an issue which concerns the whole of the east coast of Australia, for occurrences of acid sulfate soil problems really are endemic up and down the east coast. Without going into the scientific or technical aspects of acid sulfate soil, just to illustrate the problem, the main reason for what we call concrete cancer in the foundations of buildings is the release of acid sulfate soils. When released those soils are oxidised and sulfuric acid is formed, and that is what eats away at the steel reinforcing in concrete and causes concrete cancer.

speech.para: The larger problem, however, which concerns me today and which I want to illustrate is not only that it affects the foundations of buildings but also that acid sulfate soils are a very serious threat to our coastal wetlands. With the release of that material, not only is there serious pollution of those wetlands but there is destruction of flora and fauna as well. I want to illustrate this by referring to a problem in the area where I live. It is just a local issue that I have become involved in and it is simply an example of the overall problem. In the coastal area where I live there has been for some years a sandmining operation, which has now closed down. The most recent owner of that operation is the very large international company CSR, and the gravel and sand which were taken from that area were used mainly in producing ready-mix concrete. Now that the mine has been closed down there remains a very large tailings damâvery close to Elimbah Creek, which is a large creek which empties into the Pumicestone Passage, which runs between the mainland and Bribie Island and from there into Moreton Bay.

Recently, the environment department of the Caboolture Shire Council produced a report which was backed up by one of the senior water officers of the Department of Natural Resources. In that report they expressed concern about the residues in the dam; they expressed concern about the erosion of the creek bank which may, in the end, breach the dam, so that what is in there could flow into Elimbah Creek; they were concerned about the possibility of recent heavy rain flooding across the dam and into the creek; and they were concerned about leaching of material in the creek itself. All of these issues have been raised both with CSR and with the Caboolture Shire Council.

I recently attended a meeting chaired by the Caboolture Shire Council, at their invitation, in order to look at this issue. At the meeting, I questioned CSR about the council report and the Department of Natural Resources support for that report. Unfortunately, I did not get an answer. This was not necessarily entirely CSR's fault, because the meeting jumped all over the place. However, I was concerned about the behaviour of CSR as a very large international company. They seemed to want to focus on just one person in the Caboolture community who has been raising this issue for some years. I was interested that officers of CSR made statements like, `Mr Rob King has been persecuting CSR for years.' We are talking about a large international company claiming to be persecuted by an ordinary citizen. If it wasn't so laughable, one could cry.

They continued to attack Rob King, who was present at the meeting, by accusing him of telling half-truths and of putting before that meeting and other meetings evidence which they said was not true. But they really did not, in any sense, attack the evidence presented or deal with the issue. They seemed to want to spend the whole time attacking the person. There were other people at the meetingâalthough I do not know how they got there, because I was notified by the council of the people who would be there. These other people also seemed to support CSR by attacking Rob King. They inferred that he had a mental condition et cetera. I was horrified by these tactics. After all, in the end, it is the issues that count; and to personally attack someone who has, at his own expense, taken samples, who has gone out of his way to try and get the scientific evidence which could be considered by both sides in a calm way, seems to me to be a very strange tactic indeed.

I hope that the Caboolture Shire Council will seek further scientific evidence, because that is the only thing that can decide these kinds of issues. The issue is not about whether this person or some other person has caused problems for the council or for a large company; it is an issue that really ought to be decided on the evidence. To that end, I invited a friend of mine, who is a marine scientist, to spend half a day in the area examining the samples which were available and also looking at the documentationâmuch of it from CSR itself. He works for the United Kingdom environment body and also for the government in Great Britain. He lives in Australia but spends some months every year in Great Britain doing that work, as well as in Canada. I hope that the council will take seriously his research and his suggestions about what needs to be done. The concern I have is not only about the old tailings from the old mine but also about the fact that CSR is now proposing a new and much larger mine which would be located only a short distance from where the old mine is. They are proposing to mine many hectares of land, to a depth of 18 metres. I might add that this new mine will be between two large creeks, Elimbah Creek, which I have already mentioned, and Bullock Creek, both of which empty into Pumicestone Passage, which runs between the mainland and Bribie Island, as I said, and thence into Moreton Bay.

We are already having serious problems with the environment of Moreton Bay. There have been a number of reports released about the serious pollution in that area. Now we are again proposing to put that whole area further at risk. Not only is this new mine between two large creeks, but we also believe the hydrology of the area is such that both of these creeks are joined by underground streams. The new mine, as with the old mine, needs careful assessment. It is in an area which regularly floods. It is a wetlands area with a couple of rare species in itâa particular species of frog and also some colonies of the false water rat.

I know that, at the moment, the possibility of a restraining order being placed on the council by one of the environment groups is being discussed. I hope that that will not be needed. I urge the Caboolture Shire Council to act responsibly, to seek the scientific data which is needed and to do that independently of the company, so that we can all have on the table the kind of evidence which we need to make responsible decisions. My appeal to the Caboolture Shire Council today is, rather than to continue the kind of social dispute which we have had in that area, to do the work which is needed, to seek the kind of evidence which we should have and to put it on the table, so we can all be satisfied that, whatever decision is made, it is one that has been made on proper evidence.

talk.start.para: âLast time we had a matters of public interest debate in the Senate I spoke about the developing drug crisis in this country. That evening, there was a public meeting in Newcastle on the drug crisis. When we set up that meeting, I thought we might get 50 to 80 people. When I turned up to the meeting, there were 120 people there and I was quite pleased with the turnout; that was about 10 minutes before the meeting was due to start. Over the following 15 minutes, the number in the hall rose to 528. What we had was a community enormously concerned with the extent of the drug crisis in this country.

speech.para: On the eve of the state election, we are now seeing an enormous amount of belated activity from the current Labor government in New South Wales, an enormous amount of media commentary on the issue, and people coming forward and stating how this terrible drug crisis has affected them. Interestingly, it was the media which kicked off this issue. It is funny the way the media works. Something very small and very simple might very graphically and dramaticallyâin this case, one photoâdemonstrate the problem we have. That, of course, was of the childâhe was claimed to be 12 at the time but turned out to be older than thatâbeing helped to shoot up in a back alley in Redfern. That photo galvanised the community. There has been enormous concern and an outpouring of comments on public radio and in newspapers; people have written articles about it and made speeches in public forumsâas we have tried to grapple with this terrible worldwide problem.

We need to look at what we are doing in this country and what is happening, because we do have a crisis that is spinning out of control. We have a very large road toll in this country, but the toll from heroin is just as dramatic and yet does not get as widely reported. I want to congratulate the Herald-Sun in Melbourne, which, when I was looking at a copy of their paper two weeks ago, reported on the bottom of page 2 the road toll to date in Victoria as being 62 and the drug death tollâfrom heroin overdoseâas being 68. I think if that sort of public recognition of what is happening in our country becomes more widespread, we will have greater concern that state governmentsâwho have the major responsibility in this areaâactually do something effective about it.

We do not see the spectacular effects of those drug deaths. If this was something like a jumbo jet crash with over 600 people killed in one hit, it would make dramatic news; but this is not what happens with heroin overdoses. In this country, these people generally die in ones and twos. Quietly, each day, they slip away. And, as a result, it does not get much public notoriety. The extent of the problem, though, is increasing at such a rate that, in most families, people will tell you either about family members or friends or people at work or people in their street who are involved in this epidemic. The experts do not seem to have any magic bullet solutions; Premier Carr admits that his policies are failing; the New South Wales Police Commissioner announced that we had lost the war on drugs; but the question really is, `Did that war ever start?'

Confusion reigns in the minds of youth and the wider community as policy makers send mixed messages based on competing philosophies. We hear about harm minimisation and about Tough on Drugsâas if keeping our children alive and giving them back their lives were mutually exclusive. Our children have been educated about the danger of drugs but that does not stop them from experimenting and getting hooked. Even a gaol sentence does not help many addicts to kick the habit. We have a recidivism rate amongst our gaoled drug addicts of 70 per cent; they are back out on the streets again. Their families can spend much time putting their children through rehabilitation and other programs, but it is often to no availâa gram of coke can be scored when the child returns to the street.

I recently visited a drug addict in a prison in New South Wales. We had known this lad from a very early age and had lost contact with the family over the last 10 years. When asked how their child was goingâwe will call him, for the sake of this, `Jack'âwe were told, `Jack is in prison; and he has been there nearly two years. Since the age of 14 he has been a heroin addict.' Jack was released from prison two weeks ago. We keep in touch with his mother. She does not see very much of him. He is back on the streets. He is back into his old habits again.

Ironically, the minister for prisons in New South Wales, in a letter in response to this public meeting, rubbished the ideas which came out of the meeting about rehabilitation. He said, `We have got custodial rehabilitation in this country alreadyâwe have got it in the gaols. We have rehabilitation programs in the gaols.' Well, we see how effective it is from Jack's story. If we multiply the Jacks that are out there, we come to a situation where 70 per cent of those who are on drugs re-offend. They go back into the old cycle of drug useâmany of them go back into crime, which creates danger for the community, and then they go back into gaol, at a cost of $59,000 a year each. Policies are currently failing. At this time in our state of New South Wales, we have 68,000 addicts that we know about who are shooting up on a daily basisâplus a much wider range of casual users. Faced with this enormous problem, the Carr government's response is one of considerable policy confusion.

What was the Carr government's response to the photograph I referred to earlier of the boy shooting up in a back alley in Redfern? It immediately shut down that needle exchange in Redfernâjust in Redfern. It did not shut down the others. That was a total knee-jerk reaction to public pressure. How can you operate public policy on that basis? When there is some negative reaction in the community, they say, `We've seen what's happening there, we'll shut that down', but they then leave the rest of the needle exchanges open. Is the Carr government in favour of needle exchanges or isn't it? We do not know from the policy confusion that it has created.

They just axed one of the methadone programs yesterday out in Cabramatta, which had 300 clients. That is one of the major drug using areas in Australia and it is the lax attitude and approach to policing in that area that has created such a major problem. But, instead of putting resources into policing initially, they try a bandaid solution and try to fix the problem with methadone, which has increasingly come under criticism as a program, and there is policy confusion again. They shut down the Cabramatta methadone clinic but leave the others open. Where is the public policy direction in what they are doing?

The greatest failing of the Carr government's policy is its failure to provide sufficient detoxification units for people on drugs. They are absolutely desperately needed. There is one in my area in Newcastle with an inadequate number of beds. There are units in Sydney with an inadequate number of beds. But what about the Central Coast? Two hundred and fifty thousand people live on the Central Coast but there are no detox facilities. Where are the government's priorities in the rehabilitation of people on drugs when they are opening programs then shutting them down, and setting up things like detox units but not enough of them?

An even more serious situation is developing with policing. The Carr government has actually slashed the number of people policing drugs from 300 to 50. This is at a time when there has been a 50 per cent increase in heroin deaths in New South Wales since this government was voted into office. The Carr government's do-nothing policing policy means that the odds of a drug dealer getting caught in New South Wales now are about one in 2,500. That is what has happened as a result of their so-called policing policy. It is a pretty safe bet for a dealer who is aided by this understaffed police force. They would also like to turn a blind eye, because, if they catch these people, they have to put them through the court system, the gaol system and rehabilitation systems, which also creates a lot of cost. What this Carr government seems to have been doing for the last few years is actually turning a completely blind eye to the situation. The result is the enormous drug tragedy that we have before us in this nation today.

Parents in the community are demanding answers. They want effective policies developed and they want the government to get really serious about what is happening with the drug crisis and what is happening with their own children. It is interesting by historical comparison that we are not in a new situation. As the 19th century drew to a close there was a major drug crisis in this country. The crisis was alcoholâthe demon drink. At that time the community responded in quite an extensive way. Temperance movements were set up across the country. There was a major reduction in alcohol consumption in the early part of this century, when it went down by an enormous amount due to public pressure and what was happening in the temperance movements.

In dealing with our current drug problemânarcotic drugsâwe have the first glimmer of a community based approach and the public taking responsibility and initiative. This occurred in Newcastle a few weeks ago when 528 people came along to the meeting. The people who came were interesting. Because of the way we had set the night up, a lot of them had the opportunity to speak. We had drug addicts, ex-drug addicts, parents who had lost their children to drugs, health and community professionals, police officers, prison officers, church ministers, members of parliament and concerned citizens, who all gathered for three hours in search of solutions. Many of them, as I said before, had the opportunity to speak.

We heard from anti-drug campaigners Susan and Allan Forrester, who told the meeting that they had spent seven years and $50,000 fighting the heroin addiction of their daughter. They saw what drugs had done to their family and they did not want to see it happen to others. Youth Off the Streets convenor, Father Chris Riley, delivered the central message of the meetingâthat most of the kids want their lives back and they want innovative rehabilitation programs that will help them.

Angela Wood, mother of Anna Wood, told us in her inspirational talk about what she does in the New South Wales schools, educating many youth to avoid drugs. At the end of her talk at the meeting one of the senior high school pupils got up and said, `Please come to my school.' Hope for the future came from what we were told about the Swedish experience where a get tough on drugs approach, combined with education of both parents and children, has over the last 20 years reduced drug addiction dramatically.

The current programs that we have are not working effectively. The scale of the drug crisis that is upon us requires all levels of government, community, families and individuals to become involved in finding wideranging, effective measures. No matter how much government spends on protecting our borders, fighting drug crime, education and drug rehabilitation, it will never be enough to rid Australia of this scourge. The response needs to be at a community, family and individual level. The Newcastle meeting was a start. It is a community based model that other towns and cities should emulate for our children's sake.

talk.start.para: âToday I want to talk about a very important event that is occurring in Geneva on Friday, when the Australian government will report back to the special committee responsible for monitoring Australia's meeting of its obligations under the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination.

speech.para: It is probably unusual for me to commend and praise the Attorney-General, because on a whole range of human rights issues praise does not often come from me to this government. But I want to pay tribute to the Attorney-General today, and I am sorry that Senator Vanstone is not still on duty in the chamber. Legislation had been introduced to abolish the position of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner. This position had been held very ably by Mr Mick Dodson, who continues to be a very strong advocate in the Australian community for the recognition of indigenous human rights.

It was an original decision of government that the position could disappear, or at least be linked with the race discrimination position. Now, to his eternal credit, the Attorney-General has rethought that policy, announcing only last week that the position has been reinstated. He has announced the appointment of Bill Jonas, formerly of the National Museum, but before that I knew him for his excellent work at the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies. That is the first pieceâand I fear the only pieceâof good news that the Australian government will have to present to the committee in Geneva on Friday. But I do give due credit to the Attorney-General for at least ensuring that that concern expressed by the United Nations has indeed been met.

However, I would like to draw unfavourable comparisons between the report that has been prepared and presented by the Attorney-General's Department and that prepared by ATSIC. The government has prepared a 16-page report compared with ATSIC's report, which is 132 pages in length and is extremely thorough. It is an extremely useful document, because it covers a range of issues from the time when Australia last reported, when Robert Tickner himself appeared before the committee.

While Australia was praised for a number of initiatives, in 1994 there were a number of areas of concern. What we are concerned aboutâand certainly the ATSIC report indicates that they are concernedâis that the relevant suggestions made by the Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination in 1994 relating to the pursuit of an energetic policy of recognising rights and furnishing compensation were not implemented by my government in that period between 1994 and March 1996, and more particularly there has been a downgrading of indigenous recognition since 1996.

The detail speaks for itself. The social justice package process has been abandoned. The Howard government has announced that self-determination is no longer the policy in relation to indigenous affairs. The capacity of ATSIC to fulfil its statutory mandated functions has been consistently undermined. The process of reconciliationâwhile it was announced by the Prime Minister to be a focus of his second termâhas been undermined since by virtue of the attack on the Aboriginal tent embassy, for example. As soon as the Reconciliation Council puts out a draft document that states how important an apology is, the Prime Minister immediately jumps in and says, `Oh, no, no. We cannot have an apology.' Mr Howard is now one of only two current Australian leaders who has not been prepared to stand by a formal apology on behalf of his government. It has been done in every other state. It was not done in Queensland under the Borbidge government, but Peter Beattie certainly made his position clear during that debate when the resolution was not successful.

We have a new Chief Minister in the Northern Territory; I do not know his position. But at the moment it could be that, if the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory is prepared to issue a formal apology, then Mr Howard, as Prime Minister, would be the only leader not prepared to make that statement and all that goes with it in terms of its meaning to indigenous people.

There are a number of areas of concern and obviously these will be more fully scrutinised in Geneva on Friday. I hope that the government will ensure that there is a public report of that process and a public statement as to what the government is prepared to do as a result of being hauled before the special committee in Geneva. This is the first time a developed Western country has been asked to explain its policies to the United Nations committee. In moving on from the specifics of what the committee will be concerning itself with, I want to particularly focus on two policy areas. I want to mention mandatory sentencing in the Northern Territory, particularly the gaoling of the Mirrar elders and their supporters.

Clearly, there is not very much in either of those policies that is going to foster reconciliation, that is going to assist Australia's reputation vis-a-vis ensuring that we give every indication that we are totally committed to eliminating discrimination. Australia has had a good record on human rights, and a number of governments on both sides of the political divide have done a great deal to promote human rights in Australia and indeed internationally. But I fear, and I think the fact that Australia has to appear on Friday indicates, that this reputation is in some state of jeopardy at the moment.

I want to focus now on bilingual education in the Northern Territory. In the 1994 reportâwhich, of course, was about the Keating governmentâthe committee in Geneva said that there had been an ever-increasing deference on the part of the federal government to state and territory governments. That was a failing of Labor governments; it is an ongoing failing, I believe, of the current government. When the Northern Territory government announced that bilingual education would no longer be pursued in the territory, there was not a word in opposition to this from a government member.

Anyone who knows anything about education should know that the benefits of bilingual education are enormous for Aboriginal children in terms of self-respect and their capacity to learn at an early stage when they are still very reliant on their mother tongue. There was not a word from the education minister, there was not a word from the Aboriginal affairs minister and there was not a word from the Prime Minister. We had to listen to Radio National's Lingua Franca for an excellent contribution by Christine Nicholls from Flinders University. She said:

It is difficult to interpret the territory government's decision which is endorsed by the federal government as anything but a direct attack on the relatively few remaining strong Aboriginal languages and the human rights of their ever-decreasing number of speakers. The decision will also mean job losses for many of the dedicated bilingual education workers in remote rural communities, the majority of whom are Aboriginal people. In turn, this will translate into even higher levels of unemployment amongst rural Australians, and the question of employment is significant.

And she talked about the numbers of adults employed in the program. I really recommend this programâthe transcript of which is available. It was on 5 March, and is an excellent coverage of the issues that we in this chamber should be addressing. I would like to remind honourable senators that commitment to bilingual education has already been given by Australian governments. We have signed on to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. We have signed on to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. Article 30 in our report to the UN committee monitoring compliance with the Convention on the Rights of the Child states:

In those States in which ethnic, religious or linguistic minorities or persons of indigenous origin exist, a child belonging to such a minority or who is indigenous shall not be denied the right, in community with other members of his or her group, to enjoy his or her own culture, to profess and practise his or her own religion, or to use his or her own language.
Indeed, we actually reported favourably on that point in our report in 1997. We said, and we boasted:
Australia is a multicultural societyâ
we actually used the `m' wordâ
and recognises the rights of people from minority and indigenous groups to enjoy their culture, profess and practise their own religion and use their own language.

This is what concerns me about the way in which the present government is dealing with our very fragile reputation in regard to indigenous rights and human rights more generally. We say things in a certain report and then we come home and forget all about it. We are committed under those two conventions. As recently as 1997 there was a statement of recommendation from the General Assembly of United Nations which called on state parties to recognise and respect indigenous distinct culture, history, language and way of life.

It has been said before, and I am sure it will be said again and again: Australia cannot afford the luxury of turning its back on these fundamental rights of indigenous peoples. We are under close scrutiny. We are under close scrutiny because of our history, because of the White Australia policy, and this will only escalate in the lead-up to the Olympic Games. I call on the education minister, the Aboriginal affairs minister and, indeed, the Prime Ministerâif he is genuinely committed to reconciliation and to forging a strong relationship with indigenous peoplesâto talk directly to the Chief Minister in the Northern Territory and ask for a review in relation to bilingual education and call for a review in relation to mandatory sentencing. They are two policy areas in the Northern Territory that will bring shame to Australia, and we cannot afford to let this moment pass without the Prime Minister or one of his senior ministers taking direct action to try to persuade the Northern Territory government to bring its policies into line with what Australia has already agreed to.

talk.start.para: âThe subject I want to bring up todayâparthenium weedâmay not be a subject which rivets city based members and senators, but I can assure the Senate that the parthenium weed is a curse to many people in rural Australia. The parthenium weed came to Central Queensland in the early 1960s from the US. Since then it has spread a considerable distance not only on pasturage but also into pristine country and national parks. It grows so tall that it is difficult to see and muster cattle in it. At a height of only four inches, it can seed at any time of the year and it then proceeds to choke everything around it. It regenerates quickly with little rain, which is why it is causing so much trouble now, following the drought in Queensland.

speech.para: From Clermont originally, the parthenium weed is now to be found around Charters Towers, Julia Creek, the Central Highlands and the Northern Territory border. It is in the upper reaches of the Murray-Darling system and in the Bulloo and Cooper catchment areas. It can be found from Wide Bay to Roma to just outside of Rockhampton to Injune. Queensland, New South Wales and the Northern Territory are affected, and other states will follow if something is not done soon.

The parthenium weed travels by water, farm and earthmoving machinery, stock trucks and stock and chicken feed. It causes serious allergies in humans and respiratory problems, particularly for asthma sufferers. Treatment has included washdown facilities and spraying on properties. This is extremely costly and time consuming. Properties in the wool growing areas no longer have the resources to contain the spread of the weed. One property, for example, employed 10 men for a week and still could not complete the treatment.

A national coordinated approach is needed. State governments have done very little, which is why the problem now facing us is so large. What was once a self-manageable problem has now gotten out of control and must be addressed. There is hope that a rust or fungus treatment may prove successful in the future following further research into biological control methods.

The federal government is taking this matter very seriously. Only last month, the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry announced a $150,000 grant to the Parthenium Action Group. The Nationals and Liberals will continue to pursue this issue and the assistance options available to Landcare groups and property owners at a state and federal level.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 1.55 p.m. to 2.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Has the minister's attention been drawn to recent claims by the Epworth Hospital in Melbourne that digital television test transmissions almost wiped out the hospital's cardiac monitoring system? Is it a fact that public and private hospitals have been using channels 6, 8 and 9A of the VHF spectrum for medical telemetry for many years? Was your department's advice sought when the federal government decided to sell licences to that part of the spectrum to com mercial television stations in 1997? Is it a fact that hospitals were neither consulted nor even informed of this decision and that Epworth Hospital, which has long been a registered user of the spectrum, only found out when Channel 7 began test transmissions in preparation for the government ordered switch to digital broadcasting?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Conroy for the question. I think I read that in the papers a couple of weeks ago. I am pleased that Senator Conroy has got up to pace.
âOrder! Senator Faulkner, cease shouting across the chamber. I call the chamber to order and ask that the minister be heard.

âI am pleased that Senator Conroy reads the papers and that he is informed about this matter. I think Senator Conroy would also be aware that responsibility for this issue rests primarily with the Australian Broadcasting Authority and the Australian Communications Authority.

answer.para: This issue arises because some medical telemetry equipment operates in frequencies in the broadcasting services bands which will be needed for digital television transmission. Medical telemetry equipment operating in frequencies primarily provided for broadcasting services do so under a class licence made by the Australian Communications Authority which permits the operation of equipment but does not provide protection from interference by other equipment.

I am pleased that the opposition is listening, because that is an unusual occurrence. Not all medical telemetry equipment operates on frequencies within the broadcasting services bands. Senator Conroy may be interested to know that equipment operating outside these bands will not be affected by these trials.

Contrary to the suggestions made in the newspaper article, the Australian Communications Authority and the Australian Broadcasting Authority have been working over many months with the Therapeutic Goods Authority, the College of Biomedical Engineers and product suppliers to raise awareness amongst the users of this equipment of the implications of digital transmission trials. I am advised that the Therapeutic Goods Authority recommended to hospitals that they conduct an audit of their telemetry devices and that they contact their local television stations about the timing of possible test transmissions.

In the case highlighted by the Age newspaper, HSV7 placed a notice in the Age on 3 February 1999 of its intention to conduct trials following the issue of a test permit by the Australian Broadcasting Authority. Subsequently a meeting was held with a number of hospitals, health care networks, the Victorian Health Care Association, the Victorian Department of Human Services and telemetry service organisations, and arrangements were made to ensure that hospitals were informed of the trials and that HSV7 was aware of those hospitals likely to suffer interference. HSV7 conducted trials at relevant hospitals and concluded that, at the signal levels proposed for the trials, interference was unlikely.

The ABA is requiring television stations seeking licences to conduct digital trials to liaise with their local hospitals to minimise the risks of interference. The ABA is also contacting all state and territory health departments to advise them of test transmissions. At the same time, the Australian Communications Authority is examining the spectrum requirements of medical telemetry equipment in the light of changed demands on the broadcast services bands.

talk.start.para: âI ask a supplementary question. Can the minister confirm that mobile cardiac monitoring units are unable to distinguish between the signals coming from the patients' hearts and the incoming television signals? Given that a cardiac telemetry system in Sydney was obliterated for more than a day in a not-for-profit hospital due to a digital transmission, what obligation does the Commonwealth government have to notify hospitals of these changes? Who is going to foot the bill for the $400,000 that it will cost Epworth to replace its equipment? When will hospitals be informed of which part of the bandwidth they will be able to use?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âSenator Conroy obviously did not listen to the answer. I will repeat the answer for his benefit. A meeting was held with a number of hospitals, health care networks, the Victorian Health Care Association, the Victorian Department of Health and Human Services and telemetry organisations and the ABA is contacting all state and territory health departments to advise them of test transmissions.

answer.para: As hospitals are the prerogative of the state health department, I suggest that they contact Mr Carr, the Premier of New South Wales, who is responsible, and Dr Refshauge, the health minister in New South Wales, if they have a problem with the delivery of health care.

talk.start.para: âIt was actually a Victorian problem.
âSenator Conroy is not aware that hospitals are the prerogative of the state divisions.
âEpworth is in Victoria.
âMadam President, I raise a point of order. The supplementary question referred to a hospital in New South Wales, and we have got a pack of hyenas here all being allowedâ
âSenator Alston, withdraw that.
âWe have got a gaggle of senators from the other side prepared to interrupt Senator Herron and not even allow him to answer the question that was asked.
âThere is no point of order. The noise coming from senators on my left is such that it is absolutely intolerable and totally in breach of standing orders.
âMadam President, I was asked a question about a hospital in New South Wales and I replied. (Time expired)

âMy question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The latest ACCI Westpac survey of industrial trends has provided further confirmation of the strong performance of the Australian economy under the Howard government. How does this sustained strong performance of the economy fit in with the government's commitment to provide in creased job opportunities to the unemployed, particularly young Australians?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âIt is true that a strong economy is the basis for further job opportunities. It is the starting point. Without a strong economy you are simply not going to achieve the employment growths that are desirable. We are therefore pleased that we have been able to deliver to this country a strong economy, arguably the strongest economy in the world now, the strongest economy in the OECD, even stronger than all of the G7 countries. That is quite an achievement when you consider that we took office with a $10 billion deficit left by the previous Labor government. In just three years we have been able to deliver economic growth of 4.7 per cent, which most commentators regard as remarkable. Out of that growth we can give low interest rates and low inflation, and we have given reform to industrial relations, that really does offer better job prospects for all Australians, particularly young Australians.

answer.para: But a strong economy, as I said, is not enough. Further reforms are necessary. Reforms to taxation, of course, are necessary to enable business, in particular small business, to continue to grow and employ. But other policies are necessary as well, and youth wage rates are a part of that package. The Labor Party on the other side wishes to abolish youth wage rates, wishes to offer to the young people of this country a legacy of less hope, less chance for the future.

talk.start.para: âThat's not true. You can't tell the truth, can you?
âOrder! Senator Cook, stop shouting. You are behaving in a totally disorderly fashion. There is an appropriate time for you to debate this issue if you have some disagreement with the minister.

âSenator Cook, part of a Labor government which gave to this country a million unemployed, stands there and condemns the government that gives the lowest unemployment for years. What do commentators in industry say about the youth wage? Charlie Bell from McDonald's, who employs nearly 45,000 young people, said of labour:

answer.para: This will reduce the employment in Australia, and this is a big issue. It should be one of the burning issues on the mind of every community leader and every business person.
Also from McDonald's, Julie Owens said:

We'd have to stop recruiting young people virtually immediately and assess the situation. The existing staff I think would get fewer hours. We'd have to look seriously at doing business a little bit differently to remove some of the labour from the stores.
This is the Labor Party position. It results in less jobs for young people. Phil Naylor from the Australian Retailers Association said:
It has the impact of probably eliminating between 170,000 and 180,000 jobs from the retail industry.
Rob Gerard said:
A diabolical day for Australian youth.
What did Mike Paterson from the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry say? He said:
Getting rid of junior rates will drive some young people out of work, will raise business costs, will push prices up. Where any good can come from this is hard to see.

What did Mr Beazley say to this? He said he was chuffed that the Senate threw out the government's reform. That is Mr Beazley's attitude to the young who are looking for jobs. He is chuffed that they are going to get less opportunity for jobs. The Labor Party ought to read the Sydney Morning Herald editorial of today, which said:

. . . it allows Labor to pretend that it stands for "fairness" and against the "exploitation' of youth when in reality it is standing in the way of labour market reforms that would benefit young peopleâand their parents.
Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThat is what the policyless Labor Party is all about today.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senators on my left.
âMr Beazley has cleaned the slate and wiped out all Laborâ

âOrder! There has been persistent shouting on my left during the answer to this question. This is in contravention of the standing orders, which every one of you knows. I ask you to abide by the standing orders and behave in a way that others are able to hear the answer.

âMadam President, I raise a point of order. The point of order is that the standing orders for question time provide that ministers in answering questions will not debate the issue. Senator Hill is debating the issue about what Mr Beazley is alleged to have said or not and misleading the Senate as to the truth of the Labor Party position. Because he is debating the issue and misleading the Senate as to the truth of the Labor Party position, it is, I submit, with respect, understandable that that would marginally agitate us on our side. Madam President, if you would be kind enough to direct Senator Hill to conform to the standing orders, not debate his answers and stick to providing the information the question seeks, then there will be a less rowdy chamber, I suspect.
âThere is no point of order. The level of interjections is unacceptable.
âI will finish with the Sydney Morning Herald editorial. It states:

answer.para: If Mr Beazley wants his party's policies to stand up to closer scrutinyâ

talk.start.para: âTime.
âOrder! Senator, your time has expired.
âHe is going to have to tailor them to the needs of the times rather than the prejudices of the past.
âSit down.
âSenator Faulkner, I will draw the minister's attention to the time.
âWell, why don't you sit him down?
âSenator Faulkner, when the clock went off I immediately called order to Senator Hill. You were shouting so loudly he did not hear it.
âHe kept talking.
âYou were shouting and your behaviour is unacceptable.

interjection.para: interjecting â

talk.start.para: âOrder! This is supposed to be question time and the behaviour in the chamber is unacceptable.

âMy question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Can the minister tell us on what legal grounds the Department of Health and Aged Care is continuing to refuse to disclose the dates of signature on the MRI contracts signed prior to last year's budget?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âThere have been calls for an inquiry into the allocation of MRI licences, and that is what Senator Evans is referring to. There was considerable questioning during the Senate estimates committees in that regard. By way of information, I should tell you that this government introduced new and expanded funding and delivery arrangements to improve Australian's access to MRI services from 1 September 1998. Medicare benefits are now available for MRI services and consumers now have access to a wider range of MRI services and greater choice as services provided by both the private and public sectors are now eligible for funding.

answer.para: Prior to our coming to government they were restricted to the public hospitals. There was considerable demand. There has been an enormous advance in the availability of MRI scanning to the general community. This enormous advanceâthe Labor Party had no program when they went to the election to introduce this; we have introduced itâhas allowed freedom of choice within the community. We have funded that.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I take a point of order. I would appreciate it if I could get an answer to the question. The question asked what legal grounds the government had for refusing an answer to the question. I am not interested in general debate about MRI.
âThe minister certainly cannot give legal advice but I would draw his attention to the question that was asked and ask him to deal with it.

âI take a point of order. My point of order is this, Madam President. The minister was not asked for legal advice. He was asked on what grounds the legal advice was refused. That is a very different issue.
âI have drawn the minister's attention to the question and also pointed out that he cannot give legal advice but should apply himself to the question.

âMadam President, I thank you for explaining to the opposition the standing orders of the Senate, which they seem to be unaware of. You have commented yourself on the incredible behaviour of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate this afternoon.
âSenator Herron, I draw your attention to the question that you have been called to answer.

âThank you, Madam President. As they should know, any advice that the minister may have sought in this regard is something that has been discussed previously. I think it has been discussed in the Senate estimates hearings. I will check with the minister to see if he has anything further to add to the answers that were given in the Senate estimates committees.

âBy way of supplementary, again I would ask the minister to detail on what legal grounds he is refusing to disclose that information. Will the minister also undertake to provide to the Senate details of both the number of contracts under investigation and the dates of the signatures on the contracts signed before the 1998 budget decision? That is the public policy question we want answers to.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe premise of the supplementary is again absurd. Senator Evans knows that it is not necessary to seek legal advice about letting contracts for the purchase of MRI equipment. All they have to do is fulfil the requirements of the government in the tender process. As I said in my previous answer, this whole witch-hunt, which has been carried on for some months now, has nothing in it. There is a paucity of policies from the opposition. They are a policy free zone, lost in space out there, looking for something. They are dredging up matters. If there wasn't a leadership battle within the Labor Party at the moment we would not have these fatuous questions in the Senate. The whole of their response this week has been related to the leadership of the Labor Party. (Time expired)

âMy question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. As you are aware, Minister, the government's Work for the Dole project has given thousands of young Australians the chance to get a start. Will you inform the Senate of the success of the Work for the Dole projects? Is the minister aware of any attempts to undermine such projects?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âAs Senator McGauran, I am sure, is very much aware and indeed as those on this side of the chamber are aware, Work for the Dole does offer young Australians, in particular, hope, experience and opportunity. It not only provides them with necessary work experience but it engenders a work ethic; it makes it relevant to their lives. Indeed, the Daily Telegraph's editorial today said:

answer.para: The scheme creates a work ethic for young people, provides training and nurtures a sense of responsibility and achievement that cannot be attained through merely collecting the dole. It gives them credibility in the eyes of prospective employers.
It is not, as some members of the union movement would have it, a punishment for young people who cannot find employment.

To date, over 18,000 young Australians have benefited from their personal involvement in Work for the Dole schemes. To date the success rate is around 32 per cent in getting participants into paid employment, comparable to or better than the failed labour market programs under Working Nation and far more cost-effective. The people's paper, reflecting the views of ordinary mainstream Australians, understands that this is a very sensible and enlightened initiative that does offer every encouragement to young people. Why is it that such an initiative can be opposed root and branch by the Labor Party? For example, Martin Ferguson on radio a couple of years back said:
Are you trying to tell me that 1Â½ or two days per week is going to give these people the discipline of work? They go home and go back to bed or watch TV for the rest of the week.
That is what Mr Ferguson thinks the work ethic is all about.

This has most recently been highlighted by the fact that in New South Wales the trade union movement has been given an absolute power of veto. This is a disgraceful and appalling state of affairs. It is a tragic abdication of responsibility. It sends an appalling message in the lead-up to the New South Wales state election. The Premier of New South Wales made it very clear that it is important for all union organisations and others contemplating offering these sorts of arrangements to considerâmeaning consult, meaning allow them to roll over youâwith the New South Wales public sector unions.

talk.start.para: âAre you plagiarising the Telegraph again?

âThe spokesman for the AWU should know all about this. They have got their seat in the Senate chamber and he has a lot of other mates here as well. The New South Wales National Parks and Wildlife Service actually wroteâ

answer.para: Senator Carr interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âYou do the shouting, the unions call the shotsâwe understand it. If Kim Beazley cannot even show sufficient leadership to intervene in Victoria and straighten things outâ
âSenator Alston, I draw your attention to the question.

âMadam President, I was very much wanting to make the point that the New South Wales National Parks and Wildlife Service actually wrote to a project sponsor saying that unfortunately the unions would not give their approval for the projects to go ahead. What a damning indictment! What does that tell you? It tells you that the state government and the federal opposition are not in the slightest bit interested in anything that conflicts with the unions' view of the world. They are not interested in helping young people get into work and obviously, as we discovered yesterday, they are not inter ested in reducing youth unemployment. Indeed, Mr Beazley is out there saying he was very chuffed with the result. Of course he is chuffed because he has delivered to his masters once again. It is a great tragedy that this is what leadership on the Labor Party side of politics is these days. All you do is go around telling people they can like it or lump it, but you do not actually address any issues. Mr Beazley has got his opportunity next Tuesday. He is making a `vision statement'. (Time expired)

âMy question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. I ask the minister if he is aware of a recent article by Mr Gatjil Djerrkura, Chairman of ATSIC, in which he states:

question.para: ATSIC is the most accountable government authority in the country and yet the present minister and his staff have set about creating a totally false impression. While the Prime Minister talks of reconciliation, Senator Herron flies around the country at taxpayer expense preaching and practising recrimination. He has little or no understanding of the need to recogniseâ
Government senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSenator Bolkus, resume your seat. I cannot hear the question that is being asked for the noise on my right. Senator Faulkner and Senator Alston, stop shouting across the chamber.
âThe quote continues:

question.para: He has little or no understanding of the need to recognise genuine political advocacy on behalf of indigenous people.

What hope has the government got of achieving its proclaimed goal of national reconciliation when the minister responsible for Aboriginal affairs is at such loggerheads with the leader of the key national representative body for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Bolkus for the question. I am aware of that newspaper article and I am aware of another that says:

answer.para: . . . the new minister was doing the usual and travelling all over Australia to meet Aboriginal people. His line then: "It is essential that we achieve a fundamental shift from Aboriginal Affairs being a combat zone to an arena of bipartisan co-operation and moving forward."
That was written on 6 January 1996. It goes on:
Welcome to the tortured life of Robert Tickner, Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Your classic sincere leftie.
It also stated:
Paul Keating calls him "boofhead". Insiders call him "the beachball", constantly tossed between the main players with no power to change the playâ

talk.start.para: âOn a point of order, Madam President: I asked this minister a serious question about the prospects of reconciliation when he has offended the peak key Aboriginal body in this country and its chair, a person he appointed, and he is rambling on about some issue some four years ago. Can you bring him back to the question?
âThe minister has discretion as to how he answers a question, but I would draw his attention to the content of the question.

âMadam President, I was, by way of preamble, mentioning that that is not an unusual occurrence in relation to this portfolio. I plead for a bipartisan reaction. You will recall Senator Bolkus said that the reaction to the tent embassy protesters was `a cowardly act of racial violence'. Former Senator Gareth Evans accused the Prime Minister of enjoying `bashing black fellows'. Daryl Melham, my opposite number, accused the government of being like the Ku Klux Klan with his `white sheets and burning crosses' slur.

answer.para: Senator Bolkus should be aware that for 30 years there has been a difficult relationship with the aspirations of some indigenous leaders of this country and the responses of the government of whichever political colour is in power at the time. The effect of 13 years of Labor produced that article that I just referred to in the Sydney Morning Herald on 6 January 1996 where my predecessor was pilloried in the press with far more serious allegations than the content of what Senator Bolkus referred to. I am available at all times to the ATSIC leadership. In fact, I had discussions with Mr Gatjil Djerrkura yesterday. It could well be that the media department is run by the ALP, as far as I know.

talk.start.para: âIt goes from bad to worse.

âIt could well beâI am not suggesting that it is, but it is worth investigation. Frequently the reportage of events is done in a political context to achieve a certain outcome. Perhaps Senator Bolkus should consider it in that context.

âThat is an astounding answer. I remind the minister that Mr Djerrkura said that Senator Herron flies around the country preaching and practising recrimination.
