talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to speak on the issue of voluntary student unionism, which has been a matter of great debate in this country over recent years. We now have a bill about to come into the parliament, so I would like to lay down the case for voluntary student unionism tonight.

speech.para: I have spent a total of 25 years in universities as a student and an academic and I currently have four of my children in four different universities in the country. So I have had a longstanding interest in and appreciation of student life, having observed from very close quarters and also from a distance, as a student and as the father of students, the operation of student unions in this country.

I do not believe that student unions should be disbanded. I believe that they have a lot of worthwhile services and products to offer to the student population. But, as a former student union member who over many years has contributed a lot of money to student unions, I do feel they should be restructured. Those organisations should become much more efficient and be tailored to the demands of students, who should be free to choose, just as they will be free to choose when they leave university.

So far I have only hinted at the essential point, that is, the right to choose. That is one of the foundations of our democratic system. Compulsory student unionism, as it stands, is an infringement on the right of free association, as enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Free association is a basic human right and a cornerstone of our free society.

Senator Natasha Stott Despoja, a Democrat, has said that she believes in `universal membership' of a student organisation. That is a loosely veiled term for the current systemâa system of `compulsory universal membership'. This contradicts not only the human rights declaration but also the Workplace Relations Act of 1996.

Higher education and what happens there should be brought into line with what is now happening in the rest of the community. Individuals have the right to associate or dissociate at will. At present students are denied these rightsâfirstly, by being forced to join; and, secondly, by being forced to pay a fee, under threat of not being able to graduate if such fees are not paid. Some universities do offer people who dissent from joining the right to donate funds to charity. But this is not widely publicised and rarely is it invoked.

Failure to comply with joining a student union has resulted in these outcomes. In 1994 a student at the University of Tasmania who had achieved a position on the Dean's Honour Roll was expelled for refusing to pay union fees. In 1980 I was doing a PhD and was greatly concerned that my fees were being used at that time to send money to the Palestine Liberation Organisation. I objected to that and refused to pay the fees. The union said, `That's fine, you just won't graduate.' It holds that stick over the student's headâyou do not graduate if you do not pay the fees. In a free society, that is an absolutely disgraceful situation.
We find that student newspapers are run that are not necessarily in accordance with what students would want. We have found newspapers with subversive material in them, such as how to shoplift.
An opposition senator interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âYou might laugh, Senator, but I do not think that teaching students to break the law has very much to do with education. This was at La Trobe University in 1995, the publication was Rabelais and the article was on how to shoplift. Are you really condoning that, Senator? If you are, perhaps you should stand up and put it on the record.

speech.para: These publications, under a voluntary student unionism system, would be forced to appeal to a wider section of the community. Unviable services under such a system would also be forced to close. Basically, under VSU, you end up with the services that the students want. At the moment we have large amounts of money being poured into clubs and societies which have very few members and receive large grants. These sorts of funds would be moved into areas of wider appeal.

As Senator Synon pointed out in her 16 February adjournment speech, the Western Australia Student Guild at the Edith Cowan University has struggled financiallyânot because of VSU but because, before VSU was introduced, it pursued a whole lot of political ends, wasted student money and ended up with the university having to bail it out to the tune of $100,000. Recently in one of our party meetings, an MP highlighted, by passing around material, what some of this funding ends up doingâthat, of course, is being spent on anti-government propaganda. In one electorate, compulsory student fees were spent in attempting to unseat a local Liberal member; $40,000 of student money was spent on that exercise in Victoria. Such political endeavours are supported by a minority of students who elect who controls the union.

But students do not want this. What they want are services pertaining to their degree. They want value for money. But they have an invisible hand directing the flow of their compulsory contributions; and that is done by the small minority. They want accountability and responsibility. Although only 20 per cent of the student population voted in student elections, the National Union of Students spent $100,000 on a `Put the Liberals last' campaign in 1993. Such abuse of guaranteed funds is not in the best interests of the student population. With trade union backing, similar amounts were spent on anti-coalition material in 1998, targeting marginal seats. Prime Minister John Howard was subjected to abuse from 100 protesters with laser printed placards while his daughter attended her graduation ceremony at university.

In contrast to these things which in recent times have been happening in Australia in five out of six states, including New South Wales, I would briefly outline the Western Australian experience. In that state, since 1995, voluntary student unionism has worked very successfully. That has been as a result of the Western Australian parliament passing amendments to the Student Guilds and Associations Act 1993. It disallowed any compulsory fee being levied on students for non-academic services.

It is the most comprehensive, simple and successful model of VSU available. Initially, when introduced, it meant that membership went from 100 per cent down to 20 per cent. But as student groups adapted to what students need, it rose again to half the student population. The other half did not think it was worth while and they asserted their democrat ic right not to participate. Since that time, membership prices in Western Australian universities have dropped, and the guilds have been made accountable, efficient and responsible to the demands of the student population.

Increased services have come in since 1994. Curtin University gained a casual employment service, resume writing and employment services and printing services. These are degree and career related things which the students wanted. Murdoch University gained a hairdresser and a cafe, and the University of Western Australia gained two cafes and a market day. This is further evidence of the market adapting to student taste.

Opponents consistently argue about the cost legislation will have upon the students. The federal government has a very effective and generous student support scheme, the Youth Allowance, and loans are available for those in need, with payments up to $340 a fortnight. VSU was designed to save students several hundred dollars on top of the Youth Allowance scheme. The solution to the very problematic CSU scheme, therefore, is VSU, where students are given the choice of those organisations they wish to join and fund, where money is redistributed to worthwhile causes and students benefit from the savings.

talk.start.para: âI want to speak about a couple of matters tonight. The first issue I want to talk about is the management of the Northern Prawn Fishery. During the recent estimates hearings, I asked some questions about the management of the Northern Prawn Fishery, fisheries worth $120 million a year. It is, therefore, a valuable economic resource. I was told by officers of the Australian Fisheries Management Authority that work has been going on since 1993 to try to get an appropriate management regime for the Northern Prawn Fishery in place. This work was largely carried out by the Northern Prawn Fishery Management Advisory Council, known as NORMAC.

speech.para: Despite attempts to control the catch in the fishery in 1993, the capacity of the fishing effort has been increasing at about five per cent per annum, largely as a result of increased efficiency. Further, the controls put in place at that timeâa limit on vessel size and engine horsepowerâhave been the subject of manipulation. Mr Meere, the Acting Managing Director of AFMA, told the committee that NORMAC recommended to AFMA a shift from A-class unitsâa system based on boat size and engine capacityâto units based on net size. He said that the AFMA board has accepted the NORMAC recommendation. Mr Meere also told me that this new system is far more flexible than the A-class unit system, enabling future changes to capacity without major disruption to operators.

He said that AFMA undertook a process of public consultation, in accordance with section 17 of the Fisheries Management Act, in relation to this new system. That process involved, firstly, the release of a draft plan and then extensive consultation. I asked Mr Meere about the actual decision making process in relation to this plan, and he confirmed that AFMA is a statutory authority charged with the responsibility to maintain a sustainable fishing industry. Mr Meere also confirmed that, in relation to the operation of AFMA, the role of the minister is limited. The minister oversees AFMA through key accountability provisions in its legislation. These provisions require the minister to approve the AFMA corporate plan and annual operational plan and formally accept management plans determined by the authority.

There is also provision for a formal ministerial direction to the authority but only in exceptional circumstances. The power of the minister in this regard, therefore, is very limited. For example, he could not base such a decision on the adverse impact of a measure on one particular group of operators. He would be obliged to look at the matter in terms of the management of the fishery itself.

The limitations placed on the use of this power have seen no formal direction given to AFMA since it was established in 1991. The officer advised me at estimates that AFMA provided the minister, Mr Vaile, with its agreed statutory management plan for the Northern Prawn Fishery for his formal endorsement at the beginning of February this year. Some smaller operators in the fishery do not support the AFMA plan. They argue that smaller vessels are disadvantaged.

There was, however, a plebiscite organised by some licence holders to apply pressure to the minister to overturn the AFMA recommendation, but I understand that most of the participants in that vote are based in Queensland or Darwin. I also understand that most of these boats carry licences to fish in the Queensland East Coast Fishery and the Torres Strait Fishery as well as the Northern Prawn Fishery. As I said, this group is seeking to have the minister overturn the recommendation, and, through the member for Leichhardt, Mr Entsch, is applying considerable political pressure to that end.

The AFMA plan accommodates these concerns by including a provision to allow smaller vessels to adjust to the new arrangements over a period of two years. I assume that will enable the trading capacity over a period so some operators will sell out and some will increase their size and enhance their economic viability. Proper process has been followed in developing this new plan, and the evidence that was given to the estimates committee was that there is a great need for control on the utilisation of the resource if it is to be maintained at a sustainable level.

It is important that the minister meet his responsibilities under the Fisheries Administration Act and endorse the AFMA plan. It is important that the sustainable future of this important economic asset be put ahead of both the sectional interests of one part of the industry and the political interests of the local member. If that does not occur, we will see a serious deterioration in the prawn stocks in the fishery, which will jeopardise the future of the industry generally.

I was not intending to go beyond those comments tonight, but the comments that Senator Tierney made earlier about voluntary student unionism, particularly those about the application of funds of student unions to political campaigns and campaigns against the coalition, reminded me of the actions of this government prior to the last election when it spent up to about $20 million of public money for an election campaign, in effect, to promote what it proposed as laws, matters which had not even been presented to the House of Representatives let alone passed through the parliament. But it chose, without the authority of the Australian people, to expend money by executive fiat in the sum of almost $20 million to promote what was essentially its campaign at the ensuing election which was to occur shortly after the release of those funds.

For opposition senators, be it Senator Tierney today or Senator Abetz yesterday, to complain about those activities in relation to this issue of voluntary student unionism is, I suggest, quite hypocritical. I think they need to have a close look at themselves. If they are going to purport to take the high moral ground on the question of the activities of student unions, they had better have a good look at the government of which they are part.

talk.start.para: âI wish to raise a matter which is of great importance to many Australian consumersâthat is, the use of infomercials to make outrageous claims about products. But one particular product gives me reason to rise here tonightâthat is, a herbal product, which claims to be medicinal, by the name of MemAd. MemAd has an interesting claim to fame because the promoters of this drug claim that it will, amongst other things, maximise your memory, maximise your brain power and make you an overnight success in exams.

speech.para: Today I saw this product advertised at 9.30 a.m. on Win Television, but it was not the first time I had seen the infomercial run. I first saw the infomercial about a month ago on late-night television. The infomercial is marketed through Telemall Shopping, but they do not actually produce the product. I understand the person who is licensed to produce the product is Olga Sawtell. Olga Sawtell happens to also be the aunt of a rather unfortunate individual by the name of Adam Rixon, who used to be a first grade football player. Adam Rixon appears frequently through the infomercial because they claim that he went from being nearly a vegetable to having full mental capacity again simply because he took this wonderful product called MemAd. A tape of the program reveals that the compere, Ms Suzanne Paull, asked of Adam Rixon's aunt, Olga Sawtell:
So you gave Adam the MemAd and what sort of difference did you then see?
Olga Sawtell said:

Well it was all but miraculous, it all seemed to happen one day . . . and then just one day out of the blue and he said to his elder sister "but Kylie you just said" and, and, and we all cheered. Here was our breakthrough and it just, since that day it has just got better and better . . . today everyone who knows him, every member of his family, feel he has all his short term memory back and its, its just a miracle!

The problem is that MemAd is not a registered product under the Therapeutic Goods Act. The reason I sound this warning is that I do not want gullible people being suckered into a scam which would appear to have no more basis than one of Peter Foster's weight loss teas.

The fact is that not one of the claims made by the producers of MemAd has been scientifically proven. It has never been registered under the Therapeutic Goods Act. As a result, it is quite clearly illegal for these people to make these claims. The whole thing is a con, but some of the claims are really quite outrageous. Not only did we have Adam Rixon appear and his aunt and his mother but for good measure we also had his cousin. His cousin told us that he had received a letter from his school telling him he would have to leave unless his grades improved. But that was before he took MemAd. After taking the product, he said, `When it comes to the crunch, you can write down your maths formulas and your English quotes. It's all there.' He said that he went from `coming third last in the grade to the top 3Â½ per cent in the state'. The compere then asks him: `Did they suspect you of cheating?' He says, `Yes. They thought I was cheating. It was just so good.'

talk.start.para: âBryce CourtenayâThe power of one .

âThe power of one âit is not just one tablet, Senator Lundy. I will get on to that in a minute. There are many gullible people or desperate people who would love to succeed in exams and who feel, having watched this program, that all they have to do is buy the product. They might be even further duped into the buying the product because they are told that the Prime Minister of India uses the tablet. They did not say which Prime Minister. They also claimed that the No. 2 man in South Africaâand they were referring apparently to Chief Buthelezi, but they could not get his name right; they referred to him as Chief Buthali: obviously they had not taken enough of the MemAd tablet themselves to remember the nameâwas in fact a regular user of the tablet.

speech.para: When I phoned up a month ago, I pretended to be interested in buying MemAd. When I phoned up and asked about the product, they told me that the drug would `maximise brain potential'. They were their words.

talk.start.para: âYou were a victim in the first instance, Bill. Admit it. You thought you were going to get smarter.

âThey shied away from specifically saying that it would restore brain damage, but I was told that it would do pretty miraculous things. I then made a complaint to the Therapeutic Goods Administration. I will get on to how they dealt with it in a minute. I should point out that anybody suckered into buying this productâand I have not bought the productâ
âWhy not?
âBecause I am not as gullible, Senator Lundy, as maybe some of your colleagues might be. Anyone who is suckered into buying this product, buying herbal tablets, will be up for $60 a month.
âIf they remember to buy them.

âThey always get the money first, Senator O'Brien. I made a complaint to the Therapeutic Goods Administration. They then raised the matter with the licensee of the product. They made it very clearâand I want to pay tribute to the TGAâthat this product was not a registered product. It was listed, but it was not registered on the schedule, and they were not entitled to make any of these representations.

speech.para: It is my understanding that the TGA told the licensee of the product that, if they agreed to withdraw the infomercial, no further action would be taken against them, which is a very reasonable position by the TGA. I think it showed a great degree of commonsense. Unfortunately, the licensees of the product and Telemall Shopping have absolutely no regard for the law or for the Therapeutic Goods Administration or for the people to whom they sell this product.

One month after my original complaint, they aired the infomercial againânot at 1 o'clock in the morning, but at 9.30 in the morning, to get even more exposure, to sucker even more people in. They are told that if they ring in within an hour they will get a special offerâtwo months supply for the price of one.

This is a mammoth scam. It is a con. It is designed to pray on gullible people. It is quite clearly the case that there are many very good complementary medicines and many complementary medicine companies that act within the law, with restraint, with decency, with genuine concern to provide good products and good services to their customers. But MemAd is not such an operation.

MemAd is a scam and I warn all Australians to be aware of this product. I have already raised the matter with the parliamentary secretary and with the TGA. I trust that suitable action will be taken in the near future to protect people, to ensure that they do not fall victim to these people, who are preying on the gullible.

talk.start.para: âI rise this evening to make comment on the event that has been taking place here in Parliament House and around Canberra over the last few daysâthe Youth Round Table. It has been an interesting process and one that the opposition has provided much comment on since the idea was first mooted by the government. Our consistent position has been that any initiative that engages dialogue with young people in this country within the political parameters of this parliament is a positive thing. But we have also consistently maintained that in fact this round table should be supplementary to the adequate and well-established consultative processes that have existed previously.

speech.para: This issue is well on the record of the government's decisions over time to cut the support and the funding that makes the consultative peak of particularly AYPAC able to express a voice and put forward a view on behalf of the youth of Australia. The Labor position has consistently been that we actually need to build up these layers of consultation with youth in this country rather than diminish the layers and undermine their voice.

After observing the deliberations of the Youth Round Table over the last few days, I have a number of comments that I would like to make. Before I do so, I would like to acknowledge the contribution of all the young people that participated in the round table and congratulate them on their deliberations and their outcomes and wish them luck in their future endeavours with respect to their roles and responsibilities related to the Youth Round Table.

My comments go to the actual structure of the Youth Round Table and how it has been managed on behalf of the government over the last few days. No doubt there has been a flurry of activity. One of my concerns about that process is the status of this group in the eyes of the government.

The round table participants have been led to believe that they will be providing a critical voice and will be key influencers over government policy direction in the near future. This has been reinforced by several statements by the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Dr Kemp, and has been taken at genuine face value by the participants in the forum.

Words come so cheaply in politics; it will be actions that determine whether or not the government has any credibility in this regard. It is in fact too early to judge whether or not the government will follow through with this profound commitment that they have given this group of 50 young Australians.

I would like also to raise the status of the Youth Round Table with respect to the role that was previously filled by the peak youth consultative group, AYPAC. That group provided a role of bringing together information from youth organisations right around the country, consolidating it and expressing it in an articulate and concise way to governments, to oppositions and to minor parties participating in the parliament at any point in time. It seems to me that, with the marginalisation and the cutting of funds to the AYPAC youth consultative peak, the government is hopeful that the Youth Round Table will fill this great gap in the voice of youths in this country.

The question that needs to be askedâI certainly made this representation to the participants of the Youth Round Tableâis whether the government looking for a focus group with this gathering of young people or whether it is looking to create a new youth peak consultative body. It seems to me that the structure of the Youth Round Table primarily is geared towards providing the government with a very succinct insight into the views of these young people. This is incredibly important, but it also clearly defines the exercise as one of being a focus group, an opportunity for a political party or indeed, in this case, a parliamentâI will come back to that pointâto try to look inside the minds, the thoughts, the feelings and the values of this group of young people and allow them to express themselves and then to use that information to shape policy directions. This in fact is what the government has asked of this group of dynamic young people. I believe that they have actually delivered, in providing that inspiration, those thoughts, the directions to the government.

If this government is wanting more from these young people than to tap into their values and use that information for their own future development in policy, strategy and government initiative, then what are they expected to do? How will this group of people be resourced to the point that they can actually meet what is a very demanding and great responsibility, performing the role of what was previously provided by the youth peak consultative body in this country?

I watched with interest over the course of the last few days as these expectations certainly became clearer to me as to what the ongoing task was for the members of the Youth Round Table. Indeed, it is quite comprehensive. It is so comprehensive that I am gravely concerned that the government has not provided adequate resource support or information to actually allow this consultative process to occur.

I am also gravely concerned that the demands on these people as a result of this expectation will start to impinge on their lives. It would be awful if it started impacting on their lives in a negative way. It is a plea for clarification by the government as to whether or not the round table is a worthy focus group or if it is a consultative peak body of young Australians.

How on earth can you replace an organisation such as AYPAC that has established networks, communications, a skills base and a volunteer base with a group of well-intentioned young people and expect them to be able to fulfil what will be no doubt a very high public expectation of their role? My own view is that I am sure they can do it with the appropriate levels of support, but I think the Australian community will understand the importance of distinguishing those points and seeking clarification from the government as to exactly what the expectation and role of this group is.

I would like to make a couple of other points about it. I am concerned that during the week there have been a number of structural changes to the actual meeting of the round table including the cutting of focus groups and the factâand I think this is what concerns me most as a member of this parliamentâthat there was no record kept of what these young people have said over the last three days. Maybe it is because I am used to being in parliament and we have a fantastic departmental parliamentary reporting service that does record the words that are spoken in this place and provides them in perpetuity so we as politicians can forever use them as a fundamental resource. This did not occur with the round table.

In fact, I have found great difficulty even accessing the outcomes of this forum, given that I was unfortunately, depending on your perspective, in the chamber dealing with Senate business this afternoon when this group was reporting back to members of parliament in the Main Committee room. I am obviously concerned about this because I missed the event and there is no written or recorded record of the deliberations of these young people. As a member of this parliament and as a member of the opposition, I want to know if I am going to get access to this information. It is very important that my political party and I, as a member of parliament concerned about youth issues, do get the opportunity to also hear what these young people have said.

My final point is one of political manipulation. I believe the Youth Round Table is a resource to the Australian parliament. If it is just a resource for the coalition, for the government, then these young people are being manipulated. If it is in fact a resource to parliament and something that we can all participate in and get involved in, then we expect to see the information supplied to us and we expect to be invited to participate in the week's events at the next round table to a far greater degree than we were during this week.

talk.start.para: âLast weekend Melbourne hosted the Grand Prix again. Yet again the city was inundated with tobacco advertising. That tobacco advertising would normally be banned. Window displays with chequered flags and cigarette packets are only just starting to come down now. I might say that it is quite unclear whether the numerous cigarette shops, newsagents and supermarkets that carried cigarette displays have been paid by tobacco companies in cash or in kind or have even been threatened by them in order to put up those displays. We saw women, paid no doubt by tobacco companies, trawling suburban streets illegally handing out cigarettes; and no doubt they have now gone, too.

speech.para: I do not think there is much doubt that through this yearly event Australia is reversing the gains of decades of anti-smoking activism. While the Grand Prix lasts only a few days, as we know all, media coverage lasts for almost a year. Tobacco company W.D. & H.O. Wills used the race to launch a new range of Lucky Strike cigarettes. From having barely promoted the brand in Australia, the Lucky Strike logo was reportedly heavily promoted at the race itself. Only last month the wholesale prices for these new products were listed in the government Gazette. Last year I tabled in the Senate a number of magazines crammed with cigarette advertising thanks to the Grand Prix photographs.

There is absolutely no reason why media photographs or footage should not be airbrushed or digitally altered to remove tobacco company logos. After all, if Channel 7 is able to superimpose advertisements on crowd scenes, then surely it is possible to do the reverse. As it is, Australians are being exposed to tobacco advertising from other countries when we broadcast these sporting events. An example of that was last year's broadcast of the South African National Rugby Series. A plea on these grounds made late last year by the group Action on Smoking and Health to the Australian Broadcasting Authority failed. The ABA wrote that the necessary technology was not universally available to the commercial networks. They said:

The Seven Network do not . . . currently possess the ability to eliminate via computer existing advertising signage which may be visible at overseas sporting venues. However, the Seven Network has stated that it should have the necessary ability in approximately twelve months.

But this really is a matter of political will. The federal government and the Victorian government have singularly shown that that political will is lacking. Every year the federal health minister, Dr Wooldridge, exempts the organisers of the Grand Prix from bans on tobacco advertising. The caveat on the minister's approval of an exemption was that the corporation would be required to `give an assurance that no further breaches will occur'.

Save Albert Park's most recent report, Parkwatch, listed numerous breaches occurring in the 1998 race. These included tobacco advertising being displayed without the required warnings and the sale of merchandise that did not comply with the exemption. Of course, nothing was done about them. I doubt the minister had any mechanism for checking unless all of those senators and members who were there as guests of tobacco companies were keeping an eye open. But the links between the coalition and tobacco companies are very well known. We all remember that Phillip Morris sponsored the Liberal Party's national conference dinner late last year and donated $86,400 to the coalition in the financial year before the federal election. (Time expired)

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 24 November 1998:

question.para: With reference to the Commonwealth's 1996 allocation of $48.5 million for capital projects for Victorian governments schools; given that the Victorian Education Department was exempted from having to produce a list of capital projects amounting to this sum, due to the State's budget cycle:
(1) How much of the $48.5 million was ultimately spent in 1996 on capital projects in Victorian Government schools.
(2) Does the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1992 allow the money to be retained by Victoria.
(3) Has the Commonwealth requested a refund of any remaining 1996 Victorian capital funds granted by the Commonwealth.

(4) (a) How many schools and school authorities received exemptions from the Commonwealth programs for schools 1996 administrative guidelines; (b) who were they and what were the exemptions for; and (c) what section(s) of the Act or other rules or regulations permit such exemptions.

(5) (a) How many schools and authorities received exemptions from the Commonwealth programs for schools 1997 administrative guidelines; (b) how many from the 1998 administrative guidelines; (c) who were they, in each year, and what were the exceptions for; and (d) what sections of the States Grants Act or other rules or regulations would permit such exemptions.

(6) What provisions are there in the quadrennial schools funding arrangements for 1997-2000 that Commonwealth schools' monies (whether recurrent or capital) are spent for the specific purposes in the year for which they are allocated.

(7) (a) Was the "program administration" requirement in Schedule A of the agreements between the Commonwealth and each school or nominated authority, regarding "literacy, languages and special learning needs' funding, included for every school or nominated authority which received Commonwealth funds, namely, the requirement that: "To permit appropriate program monitoring, the nominated authority will advise the Commonwealth in writing of: principles applied in allocating funds; and arrangements for consulting with the relevant educational authorities and community groups on program priorities and targeting; (b) was the same requirement included for 1998 "literacy and special learning needs' for funding, for all schools or nominated educational authorities; and (c) will this requirement continue for the funding years 1999 and 2000.
(8) Of the schools or nominated education authorities with which there are such agreements, how many have provided the required Schedule A "program administration' details.
(9) Can the names of those which have not provided these details in 1997 or 1998 be provided.
(10) What measures have been taken in response to cases where the required details have not been provided.

(11) Given the vulnerability of the school children for whom these funds are being provided, what monitoring is taking place to ensure the principles and consultation are being adhered to and are actually adequate for ensuring an optimum school education.

(12) Given that under the national equity program for schools (NEPS), under which similar funding was provided up until 1996, these principles and consultative arrangements were specified in a schedule in the agreements, and the agreements themselves were public documents; is it possible for members of the public to obtain the principles and consultative arrangements supplied to the Commonwealth which have been provided pursuant to funding agreements; if so, from whom.

(13) Do details of consultative arrangements continue to include provision of names and category being represented of all members or consultative groups or committees, as was the case with NEPS; if not, why not.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator Ellison
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: âThe following answer to the honourable senator's question has been provided by Dr Kemp for your information:

answer.para: (1) All of the initial allocation of $48.5 million for Victorian government schools was committed in 1996.

The Victorian Government, because of the timing of its budget cycle, was unable to submit a complete schedule of capital projects for Common wealth funding in 1996 at the beginning of the 1996 program year. Dr Kemp, the then Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, agreed that under these circumstances the Victorian Government should be able to submit a further schedule later in the year, which it did, and which committed the remainder of its 1996 allocation.

(2) If the State of Victoria had not committed all of its allocation for 1996, the Minister, under the Act and the agreement between the Commonwealth and the State made under the Act, would have been entitled to withhold funds not committed in 1996.
(3) No, because it is not applicable.
(4) (a) Two.

(b) The Independent Schools of Queensland Block Grant Authority sought and obtained a relaxation of the requirement that 50 per cent of projects be in respect of existing student places. It was agreed that 35 per cent of projects would be for existing places because of the profile of projects submitted for Commonwealth funding in the year.

The Victorian Government sought and obtained a relaxation of the requirement to submit all capital projects it proposed for funding, in one instalment at the beginning of the year. Since the granting of this concession it has been determined that, for practical reasons, all States should be able to submit schedules of projects in more than one instalment.

(c) These conditions of funding are set out in the Administrative Guidelines to which States and block grant authorities are bound under their agreements with the Commonwealth. These agreements are required under the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1992. Subsection 47(4) of that Act applies to capital grants for government schools and paragraph 15(1)(a) to capital grants for non-government schools. The parties to agreements may agree to amend them.
(5) (a) Two.
(b) None

(c) The South Australian Department of Education and Children's Services sought and obtained a relaxation of the requirement to submit schedules of projects within two weeks of their being publicly announced. This concession was granted because of delays attributable to the holding of State elections.

The Victorian Government sought and obtained an exemption to the requirement to advise schools of the exact amounts of Commonwealth funding allocated to each project. This exemption was granted because the original cost would have been out of date by the time a Commonwealth representative attended an opening.

(d) These conditions of funding are set out in the Administrative Guidelines to which States and block grant authorities are bound under their agreements with the Commonwealth. These agreements are required under the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1996. Part 2, Division 1 of that Act applies to capital grants for government schools and Part 2, Division 2 to capital grants for non-government schools. The parties to agreements may agree to amend them.

(6) Part 2 of the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1996 contains provisions (at sections 11(a) and 16(4)) which require the State or nominated authority to provide a certificate stating whether the amount or sum of amounts of financial assistance paid to the State or nominated authority under the relevant provision of the Act for that year have been spent in respect of that year for the purpose for which the assistance was granted.

(7) The Agreements between the Commonwealth and each education authority for 1997 specified that for program monitoring purposes in respect of the Literacy, Languages and Special Learning Needs Programs, the authority would provide the Commonwealth with:
. the principles applied in allocating program funds; and
. the arrangements for consulting with the relevant educational authorities and community groups on program priorities and targeting.

The same arrangements applied for 1998. In addition, in relation to the Literacy Program, authorities were asked to provide a strategic plan on how schools would ensure that students meet the national literacy standard by the end of Year 3.
The administrative arrangements for 1999 will not be significantly different from those that applied for 1998. The arrangements for 2000 will be finalised towards the end of 1999.
The Agreements apply between the Commonwealth and education authorities, not individual schools.
(8) All education authorities have provided the required information for 1997 and 1998.
(9) All education authorities have provided the required information for 1997 and 1998.
(10) All education authorities have provided the required information for 1997 and 1998.
(11) All education authorities have provided the required information for 1997 and 1998.

(12) The Schedules to the Agreements for Literacy, Languages and Special Learning Needs contain a requirement for State Governments and nominated authorities to advise the Commonwealth in writing of the principles applied to allocating program funds and the arrangements for consulting with the relevant educational authorities and community groups on program priorities and targeting.

(13) Details provided on consultative arrangements include the category of membership of consultative groups and committees. The Commonwealth is concerned that a range of relevant advice is sought in considering funding arrangements to schools, rather than the details of the particular individuals

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 25 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister aware that Peron Island, a popular fishing area, off the coast of the Northern Territory, currently has no radio coverage, and that if anglers encounter trouble, there is no way for them to place an emergency call for help.
(2) Can an indication be given on when radio coverage over Peron Island will be available and why the Government has ignored this important marine safety issue.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Commonwealth operates a coast radio station network for distress and safety communications purposes covering the Australian search and rescue region. Peron Island falls within the Australian search and rescue region. The Island is covered by the Commonwealth's distress and safety communications network. This network is provided principally to meet the needs of the merchant shipping industry under the provisions of the International Safety of Life at Sea (SOLAS) Convention. However, smaller vessels and pleasure craft fall outside the scope of the SOLAS Convention. The responsibility for providing communication services for such vessels rests with State and Territory Governments. This reflects an agreement by Commonwealth and State/Territory Ministers for Transport in 1990. The services provided by coast radio stations are available free of charge, to pleasure craft and fishing vessels that have the appropriate communications facilities, within the radio service areas. If anglers in the vicinity of Peron Island wish to use the Commonwealth's distress and safety communications network, they may do so, free of charge, provided they are equipped with suitable communications facilities.

(2) The Commonwealth's distress and safety communications network has provided radio coverage for Peron Island for many years. Under the present contract that the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) has negotiated with Telstra, the coast radio station network, which includes the coast radio stations in Darwin, Perth, Melbourne, Sydney, Brisbane and Townsville, will continue to operate and provide radio coverage within the same service areas as have been covered to the present time. AMSA will continue to manage the provision of safety radio services by maintaining its existing levels of service until a suitable long term replacement is implemented or until 2005, whichever is earlier.

(i) $64,000âMay 1996; (ii) $36,284âOctober 1996 (funded by Environment Australia); (iii)$9,000âSeptember 1997; (iv) $16,250âFebruary 1998; and (v)$30,000âJuly 1998.

subdebateinfo.title: Private After School Hours Child Care Centres: Assistance
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 353)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 7 December 1998:

question.para: Why does after school hours care provided by private operators on school property, or property other than licensed child care centres, not attract child care assistance to parents.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Commonwealth provides funding and access to Childcare Assistance to eligible organisations such as incorporated non-profit community organisations, local government, religious and charitable or school boards/councils to provide care for school age children before and after school and during periods of school vacation. School age care services may be located in schools or other non-licensed premises such as community halls. Currently only the ACT license outside school hours care services.
New services are only approved for Commonwealth funding in areas of high need.

State/Territory Planning Advisory Committees comprising Commonwealth, State and local government representatives, banks, investment advisors networks and other relevant groups consider relevant demographic and local government planning information and provide advice to Government on priority areas which require additional child care places for work-related care.

Currently private-for-profit operators are ineligible to apply for funding to operate outside school hours care services. However, the Government is looking at future options, which may open the way for private operators to become sponsors of school age care services.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 10 December 1998:

question.para: (1) Have the states raised concerns about the 1997 assessment and approval process associated with funding from the Natural Heritage Trust; if so, what was the nature of those concerns.
(2) What action has the Government taken to address those concerns.
(3) What action has the Government taken to improve and streamline management arrangements for the assessment process.
(4) What level of resources was made available for community assessment processes and the evaluation of program outcomes in 1997.
(5) What level of resources have been made available for community assessment processes and the evaluation of program outcomes in 1998.
(6) What is the basis upon which resources were allocated for the administration and management of the Natural Heritage Trust, at a Commonwealth, state and territory level, in (a) 1997 and (b) 1998.
(7) What was the basis upon which funding was allocated between community, agency, on-ground, and investigations projects through the Natural Heritage Trust in 1997.
(8) What was the basis upon which funding has been allocated between community, agency, on-ground, and investigations projects through the Natural Heritage Trust in 1998.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: Responsibility for the Natural Heritage Trust lies with the Natural Heritage Ministerial Board, which comprises the Minister for Environment and Heritage, and the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. This reply has been prepared in consultation with the Minister for Environment and Heritage.

(1) The Natural Heritage Trust represents a more than doubling in funding for natural resource, environment and sustainable agriculture programs in most of the States. In our opinion, processes are working effectively to deliver the range of programs managed through the Trust.

1997 was a transitional year for the Natural Heritage Trust during which many of the arrangements were being put in place. In particular, this concerned the concluding of a Partnership Agreement between the Commonwealth and each of the States and Territories. The Agreements were developed in consultation with the States and Territories and set out the roles and responsibilities of the Commonwealth and the States and Territories for the delivery of most of the Trust programs. Under these Agreements, parties agreed to jointly develop consistent guidelines for project assessment and approval.

There are a number of fora in which States and Territories can express their views about administration of the Trust. These include the Australian Landcare Council and Ministerial Councils such as the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand. In addition, the Commonwealth has regular meetings with stakeholders, including the States and Territories and community representatives, to seek feedback and recommendations for improvement to the delivery of the Natural Heritage Trust. Recent stakeholder meetings were held in February and December 1998 to discuss Natural Heritage Trust processes and in July 1998 to discuss the guidelines.

An issue of concern to the States and Territories was that funding priorities identified by regional and state assessment panels were not in some instances accepted by the Natural Heritage Ministerial Board. However, the majority of proposals was accepted and those that were not successful were judged not to meet Commonwealth priorities. Additionally, States felt that the level of resources offered by the Commonwealth to support program administration was insufficient.

The February 1998 stakeholders meeting discussed a range of issues including arrangements for continuing projects, development of regional approaches to Natural Heritage Trust delivery, improvements to Trust processes and better integration of Trust administration.
The December 1998 meeting considered issues such as Natural Heritage Trust monitoring and evaluation, project payment and accountability, project reporting and alternative delivery models.

(2) The 1999-2000 Natural Heritage Trust Guidelines have incorporated many comments made by a wide range of State and community stakeholders who attended the guidelines workshop in July 1998. Particular changes to make the application process more accessible have included improvements to the layout and flow of the document, the inclusion of flowcharts and additional information to explain the application and assessment processes, a more generous definition of `small projects' which are not required to provide as much detail as larger projects, the consolidation of all eligibility questions into one chapter and the setting out of a step by step process for completing the application. In addition, the guidelines were released much earlier this year, to provide applicants with more time to develop their proposals.
In the 1998-99 round, project announcements were made considerably earlier than for 1997-98.
Assessment panels have been given wider access to technical advice. This is being provided by the States and Territories and was a recommendation of the February 1998 stakeholders meeting.
A monitoring and evaluation strategy is being implemented and uniform project reporting requirements have been developed in consultation with State and Territory representatives.

The Commonwealth also has undertaken to provide improved feedback on reasons for project rejection. Besides helping proponents to refine their projects, this will also maintain confidence in the assessment process.
(3) The actions outlined above, together with the regular stakeholder meetings, are intended to improve the management arrangements for the assessment process.

(4) Natural Heritage Trust funding was provided to States and Territories in 1997-98 to assist with administration, assessment and initial evaluation activities. The level of funds provided is detailed below. States and Territories also contribute resources to Trust administration.
Decisions about the level of funding for administration take into account continuing community concerns about program funding being diverted to bureaucracy.

(5) Tasmania is the only State which has signed an agreement with the Commonwealth for administrative support for the life of the Trust and is receiving an amount of $260 000 in 1998-99. The Commonwealth has made an offer to other States and Territories for administration, assessment and initial evaluation for 1998. States and Territories are currently considering the offer.

Commonwealth: During establishment of the Trust, the resources required to administer the Trust and its programs at the Commonwealth level were determined by Ministers and the Departments in consultation with the (then) Department of Finance taking into account benchmarks and the information provided in the 1997 Australian National Audit Office performance audit "Commonwealth Natural Resource Management and Environment Pro gramsâAustralia's Land, Water and Vegetation Resources".

State and Territory: Funds are allocated to assist in coordination of activities at the State and Territory level, particularly administration and assessment process expenses, plus an interim contribution from the Commonwealth for evaluation and monitoring costs.

In general, funds for evaluation, administration and assessment support were allocated on a pro rata basis. That is, the available funds were allocated to each State and Territory in the same proportions as the distribution between States and Territories of total Trust funds for 1997-98. The approach was modified to accommodate smaller jurisdictions to reflect a loss of economies of scale.
Commonwealth: As for 6 (a).
State and Territory: As for 6 (a).
(7) One-Stop-Shop Programs

Programs included in the One-Stop-Shop Guide to applications in 1997 were Bushcare, Landcare, Murray-Darling 2001, Rivercare (including Waterwatch), Fisheries Action Program, Farm Forestry, National Reserve System, National Weeds Program, Endangered Species, National Wetlands Program and National Feral Animal Control Strategy.

For the first six programs listed, funding applications were assessed and prioritised by community based Regional and State Assessment Panels. As such, the funding allocation largely reflected the priorities of these panels. The panels determined their priorities against the framework of the Partnership Agreements which set out, for each State and Territory, their natural resource management strategies and priorities. Commonwealth Ministers provided advice to State and Territory Ministers outlining Commonwealth priorities prior to the commencement of the assessment round.
- National Reserve System Program
- Endangered Species Program
- National Wetlands Program
Applications were assessed by technical panels relevant to each program and ranked according to national priorities determined against program objectives.
- National Weeds Program
- National Feral Animal Control Strategy
(see below)
National Weeds Program

The National Weeds Strategy Executive Committee (comprising representatives from state environment, forestry and agricultural and resource management agencies) has been established to oversee the implementation of the strategy and will identify priority weeds for national attention. The type of activity to receive Commonwealth funding will be decided on a weed by weed basis eg the funding priorities for one weed may be on ground activities, whereas for another weed funding may be directed to research.
National Feral Animal Control

The agricultural component of the program, administered by the Bureau of Rural Sciences of the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, supports a wide range of activities which will assist the development and adoption of best practice pest management.

The focus of the agricultural component is applied research that is likely to have a direct link to improved pest management at the property level. The program will generally not fund pure background research (e.g. ecology/biology of pest animals) or routine pest-management activities.
FarmBisâFarm Business Improvement Program

FarmBis consists of two components; a national component and a State based component. Minister Anderson approved the use of all the Natural Heritage Trust FarmBis funds for the State based component. A State Planning Group in each State then determines how funds are allocated according to State/industry/community agreed priorities in relation to training and education within their regional communities/rural sector.
National Land and Water Resources Audit

The Audit is a four year, Natural Heritage Trust program undertaken in partnership with States, industry and community groups to provide an independent, objective assessment of the extent of natural resource degradation and include an economic analysis of each problem. Primarily, the focus of the Audit will be on the needs of the Commonwealth and State agencies. An Advisory Council has been appointed to develop and manage implementation of the Audit.
Riverworks Tasmania
Funding was allocated to projects according to recommendations made by Consultative Committees comprising community and government representatives.
National River Health Program

The National River Health Program is a research oriented program. The National River Health Strategy, which the Minister for the Environment and Heritage approved on 14 December 1997, sets out the basis for funding under the program. The program is implemented by State and Territory agencies (in accordance with Trust Partnership Agreements), researchers and research organisations and has no community grants component.

As an interim arrangement for 1997-98 only, Environment Australia entered into an agreement with the Land and Water Resources Research and Development Corporation (LWRRDC). LWRRDC was responsible for the disbursement of funds under the Australia Wide Assessment of River Health component of the program.
Coasts and Clean Seas

Coasts and Clean Seas (CCS) has no formula for allocation of funds between these categories. CCS encourages partnerships between community, government and non-government organisations (the Coastcare program has a stipulation that applications be submitted jointly by a community group and the local management agency). CCS funding may be paid to any of the joint applicants as long as the organisation receiving funding is a statutory or incorporated body. Both on-ground and appropriate investigation projects are eligible for funding, however the focus of CCS is on practical actions and on-ground works.
Waste Management Awareness Program

Projects are agreed to by the Minister on the basis of merit in meeting the WMAP objectives which were agreed to by the Natural Heritage Ministerial Board. Funding is not allocated to projects according to `community', `agency', `on-ground' and `investigations' criteria.
Air Pollution in Major Cities
Funding allocations are based on addressing the program's priorities. The program funds projects with a national focus, rather than a regional or state focus.

Allocations in 1997 were limited to standard development (National Environment Protection Measures), continuation of a national community action program (SMOGBUSTERS) and an Independent Inquiry into Urban Air Pollution in Australia.
World Heritage Area Management

World Heritage funding is provided to States only (not to community groups). The States were invited to provide detailed project proposals. All proposals had been through a systematic consultation and assessment process (involving community and scientific advisory committees in each WH property). The State then prioritised each project and submitted the proposals to the WH Unit, which then assessed these proposals and included its own priority lists (based primarily on existing management plans), before submitting the projects to the Minister for his consideration.
(8) One-Stop-Shop Programs

In 1998, programs included in the One-Stop-Shop were Landcare, Rivercare, MD2001, Fisheries Action Program, Farm Forestry, Bushcare, Endangered Species Program, National Reserve System Program, National Wetlands Program and Waterwatch Australia.

For most programs, funding applications were assessed and prioritised by community-based Regional and State Assessment Panels. As such, the funding allocation largely reflected the priorities of these panels. The panels determined their priorities against the framework of the Partnership Agreements which set out, for each State and Territory, their natural resource management strategies and priorities. Commonwealth Ministers provided advice to State and Territory Ministers outlining Commonwealth priorities prior to commencement of the assessment round.

For Endangered Species and the National Reserve System, applications were assessed by a technical panel and ranked according to national priorities, taking account of comments from State Assessment Panels.
FarmBisâFarm Business Improvement Program
National Land and Water Resources Audit
National Feral Animal Control Program
National Weeds Program
As for (7).
National River Health Program
The basis for the allocation of funding has not altered for 1998-99, except that disbursement of all funds is now undertaken by Environment Australia.
Coasts and Clean Seas
As for (7).
Waste Management Awareness Program
As for (7).
Air Pollution in Major Cities

Allocations in 1998 were directed to priority programs identified in the report of the Independent Inquiry described in (7). Individual projects were developed in consultation with Commonwealth and State agencies to meet the objectives of the program which were agreed by the Natural Heritage Ministerial Board.
World Heritage Area Management
As for (7).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 21 December 1998:

question.para: (1) (a) What audit or review of Tasmania's integrated quarantine service has been carried out in 1997 and 1998; (b) Who conducted the review; (c) What were its terms of reference; (d) When was the report completed; and (e) What did it recommend.
(2) Can a copy be provided of any such audit or review.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

answer.para: (1) (a) A review of current arrangements in place for the delivery of international quarantine and export inspection services was undertaken in Tasmania, Western Australia and the Northern Territory commencing in August 1997. The review followed the release of the Government's response to the Nairn report on quarantine in August 1997.
(b) The review was conducted by senior officers from the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and the respective States and Territory.

(c) Recommendation 49 of the Nairn report, endorsed by the Government, called for consistent, efficient and effective national delivery and reporting of quarantine services. In the accompanying text (section 8.3.3) to the recommendation, the following comment was made "the principles underpinning the goal of quarantine are that quarantine programs should be delivered effectively, efficiently and with a consistent national approach. To ensure these principles are achieved, one agency should bear the full responsibility for provision of quarantine services. The Review Committee believes that Quarantine Australia should be that agency."
This formed the central focus for the review.
(d) The report was completed in May 1998 when the Chief Executive Officers agreed to it.

(e) The report discussed a number of options relating to the delivery of international quarantine and export inspection services which were identified from the review. The summary, on page 20 of the report, provides a synopsis of the seven key actions arising from consideration of the options; these were accepted by the respective Ministers.
(2) A copy of the report has been provided to Senator Brown and copies are available from the Senate Table Office.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Comprehensive Costs
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 393)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 December 1998:

question.para: (1) Has the Government calculated the compliance costs of imposing a goods and services tax on the charity/ not for profit sector; if so, what is the cost.
(2) Will the Government reimburse this sector fully for these compliance costs.
(3) Who will determine the amount to be paid to each entity within the sector.
(4) Does the Government agree with the Vos report on the charity/not for profit sector.
(5) Who will be on the body which will advise the Government on compliance costs and reimbursement for this sector.
(6) Will the charity/not for profit sector be able to nominate members to any body appointed by the Government to oversee the application of these measures.
(7) Does the Australian Taxation Office have a training manual to help implementation of the Government's tax reforms; if so, will the manual be made public; and when will it be made public.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âThe Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Government has not calculated the compliance costs of imposing a GST on specific sectors in the economy. The Government's Regulation Impact Statement estimates average net recurrent compliance costs for 2000/02 of $130 per registrant.

Compliance costs are likely to be reduced for charitable institutions by the Government's proposed grouping provisions, which will allow all members of the same non-profit association to nominate one member to represent the group for GST purposes.

(2) The GST has been designed and will be implemented such that compliance costs are kept to a minimum. The Government has not offered to reimburse any sector of the Australian economy for any compliance costs which might flow from a GST. The Government will spend up to $500 million to defray the start-up costs of small and medium businesses implementing the GST. The Government will consult with business through a Small Business Consultative Committee on the most effective options for delivery of these incentives. In addition, under existing provisions of the income tax legislation, many of the start-up costs associated with the GST will be tax deductible for businesses.
The Small Business Consultative Committee has also been asked to provide ongoing advice, and where applicable, options to address the compliance cost for small business.

(3) The Small Business Consultative Committee's Terms of Reference includes advising the Government on the distribution of the incentives announced in the Government's tax reform plan, A New Tax System. The Government will then decide how the incentives will be applied.

(4) The Government has accepted all the recommendations made by Tax Consultative Committee, which was chaired by Mr Vos, including those relating to the charitable sector. In addition, the Government extended the GST-free provisions to include income tax exempt charities as well as entities eligible to receive income tax deductible donations.
(5) and (6) The Government announced the establishment and membership of a Small Business Consultative Committee on 6 December 1998. Membership details are:
Chairman: Mr Curt Rendall, member of the NSW Small Business Development Corporation and Chairman of the Institute of Chartered Accountants of Australia Small and Medium Enterprises Committee.

Members: Mr Greg Evans, Executive Director of the Wool Council of Australia (Deputy Chairman of the SBCC); Ms Angela Ryan, Director of Taxation, Australian Society of Certified Practicing Accountants; Associate Professor Neil Warren, Australian Taxation Studies Program, Faculty of Law, University of NSW; Mr Ian Baldock, Chairman, Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia Ltd; Ms Dorothy Jellett, Managing Director of DFP Recruitment Services and a member of the Executive Council of the Victorian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry; Mr Peter Siekmann, President of the Australian Small Business Association; and Mr Steve Chapman, Deputy Commissioners of Taxation for Small Business, Australian Taxation Office.

(7) To assist with implementation of the Government's tax reforms, the Australian Taxation Office will conduct information and communication programs to inform both the general public and business communities about the changes to the tax system.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 24 December 1998:

question.para: Can details be provided of the total cost to the Commonwealth Government of the Yorta Yorta native title claim of the following:
(1) Funding provided to the Yorta Yorta Murray Goulburn Rivers Clan Inc. through the Native Title Fund.
(2) Funding provided by grants to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission to assist the Yorta Yorta Murray Goulburn Rivers Clan Inc. to fund the native title claim.
(3) Any and all other funding provided to fund the Yorta Yorta native title claim.
(4) The approximate cost of the Native Title Tribunal's unsuccessful efforts at mediation.
(5) All and any costs incurred by the Commonwealth for Native Title Tribunal legal representation.
(6) The cost to the Commonwealth of the tribunal's referral to the Federal Court.
(7) All and any cost incurred by the Commonwealth for Federal Court legal representation.
(8) The total cost of all legal action associated with the Yorta Yorta native title claim.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: âThe Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1)â(3) I am advised that answers to these questions have been provided by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs in his response to Senate Question No. 395.
(4) Direct costs expended by the National Native Title Tribunal on mediation of the Yorta Yorta Native Title applications amounted to $22,576.
Indirect staff and member costs for file and mediation preparation are estimated at $5,998.

(5) and (7) The Commonwealth, through the Attorney-General's Department, provided financial assistance under s.183 of the Native Title Act 1993 to a number of respondents to enable them to be legally represented in the proceedings before the Native Title Tribunal and the Federal Court. Because of the manner in which statistics are maintained it is not possible to provide a breakdown of costs between the National Native Title

Tribunal and the Federal Court. However, the overall costs incurred in providing financial assistance in both the NNTT and Federal Court proceedings as at 31 January 1999 were $3,369,713.
